Speaker: NA
Text: OTJBRENCY.

Speaker: Mr DEAN
Text: Th e question that I

Speaker: NA
Text: address to the Treasurer arises from the

Speaker: NA
Text: judgment recently given in a case in

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne, in which a person was

Speaker: NA
Text: acquitted of a charge of having counter-

Speaker: NA
Text: feited coins because, in his defence, he

Speaker: NA
Text: said tihat the counterfeit coins would he

Speaker: NA
Text: used in the manufacture of jewellery. Is

Speaker: NA
Text: it possible for the Government to protect

Speaker: NA
Text: the genuine sovereign by causing an

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment to be made to the law so aa to

Speaker: NA
Text: make the counterfeiting of gold coinage a

Speaker: NA
Text: punishable offence ?

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir ARTHUR FADDEN Thia

Speaker: NA
Text: matter is at present the subject of

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry by officers of the Treasury and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Attotirey-Geheral's Department.

Speaker: NA
Text: As soon, as a feport is received

Speaker: NA
Text: from theAttorney-General's Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, it will he considered by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, which realizes tliat the

Speaker: NA
Text: counterfeiting of gold coins is 'a most

Speaker: NA
Text: important matter that affects not Only

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia but also other members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: British Commonwealth of Nations.

Speaker: NA
Text: BERRY FRUITS.

Speaker: Mr DUTHIE
Text: I remind the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Commerce and Agriculture that a

Speaker: NA
Text: representative meeting of berry fruit

Speaker: NA
Text: interests and members of Patlia'

Speaker: NA
Text: ment was held at Hobart on the 28th

Speaker: NA
Text: June last in order to prepare a case in

Speaker: NA
Text: favour of the granting of assistance to

Speaker: NA
Text: the berry fruit industry in Tasmania,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is threatened with extinction. Can

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable gentleman tell me

Speaker: NA
Text: whether any progress is being made in

Speaker: NA
Text: response to representations that have been

Speaker: NA
Text: made to him for the revival and stabiliza-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the industry, as well as for the

Speaker: NA
Text: discovery of new markets for berry

Speaker: NA
Text: fruits at economic prices? The farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: want to know what plans to make for

Speaker: NA
Text: the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCEWEIf -Man y representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions have been made to the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: on behalf of the berry fruits industry. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, I can recall Offhand three deputa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of Government supporter S f f om both

Speaker: NA
Text: Houses that have been introduced to me.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government some time ago gave

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration to specific proposals that

Speaker: NA
Text: were made to it that, having regard to

Speaker: NA
Text: the problems of certain berry growers,

Speaker: NA
Text: a subsidy Should be paid to them. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government does not consider that prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems of this kind can be solved merely

Speaker: NA
Text: by thc payment of a subsidy ta

Speaker: NA
Text: those who are in need. There-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore, a close study was made of tbo

Speaker: NA
Text: possibility of devising a commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: solution of the general problem. As

Speaker: NA
Text: a result of the activities of tbe Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's trade commissioner service, an

Speaker: NA
Text: interested party was discovered in

Speaker: NA
Text: London and persuaded to come to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: - tralia. Last year he bought the whole of

Speaker: NA
Text: the black currant crop. This haa opened

Speaker: NA
Text: a completely new vista f o r the industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tbe policy that I have mentioned must

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to apply to the growers of otber

Speaker: NA
Text: berries i n respect of which, a commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: solution has not yet been discovered.

Speaker: NA
Text: However-, the person to whom I have

Speaker: NA
Text: referred will shortly visit Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: again, I understand, and I am confident

Speaker: NA
Text: that, as a result of the activities of the

Speaker: NA
Text: trade commissioner service, there will be

Speaker: NA
Text: an opportunity for the expansion of our

Speaker: NA
Text: black currant industry at least.

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMONWEALTH BANK.

Speaker: Mr COSTA
Text: I ask the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: whether it is true that many clients of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank are transferring

Speaker: NA
Text: their business accounts to private banks

Speaker: NA
Text: because the Commonwealth Bank is

Speaker: NA
Text: refusing to give loan and overdraft

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodation for legitimate business

Speaker: NA
Text: dealings. Is it also true that people who

Speaker: NA
Text: seek from the Commonwealth Bank

Speaker: NA
Text: nnanciai aid for home building are turned

Speaker: NA
Text: away, and advised to apply to private

Speaker: NA
Text: banks for it whilst, conversely, the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Bank is prepared to lend the

Speaker: NA
Text: same people money for the purchase of

Speaker: NA
Text: Holden motor cars? I f these are facts,

Speaker: NA
Text: will the Treasurer instruct the manage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the Commonwealth Bank to

Speaker: NA
Text: cease this unwise practice, and see that

Speaker: NA
Text: the people's bank performs the proper

Speaker: NA
Text: function for which it was founded by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fisher Labour Government?

Speaker: Sir ARTHUR FADDEN
Text: I should

Speaker: NA
Text: be surprised i f the circumstances stated

Speaker: NA
Text: by the honorable gentleman are based on

Speaker: NA
Text: fact. However, I shall inquire into the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter and let him know the position.

Speaker: NA
Text: DUTCH NEW GUINEA.

Speaker: Dr DONALD CAMERON
Text: Wil l the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for External Affairs comment

Speaker: NA
Text: on the request made by the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: of Indonesia that the problem of the

Speaker: NA
Text: sovereignty of West New Guinea be dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussed by the General Assembly of the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations? Is he of the opinion

Speaker: NA
Text: that a satisfactory solution of the problem

Speaker: NA
Text: can be found in that way? Does he con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider that the extensive economic and

Speaker: NA
Text: administrative difficulties with which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government of Indonesia is already con-

Speaker: NA
Text: fronted will permit that government to

Speaker: NA
Text: exercise over West New Guinea a

Speaker: NA
Text: sovereignty that will be conducive to poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: tical stability in that area, or indeed, to

Speaker: NA
Text: the best interests of the native inhabitants

Speaker: NA
Text: of it? Does the Minister agree that,

Speaker: NA
Text: whilst Australia desires to have the most

Speaker: NA
Text: friendly relations with Indonesia, we are

Speaker: NA
Text: bound, in the interests of our own security

Speaker: NA
Text: to be concerned about the sovereignty

Speaker: NA
Text: of that area?

Speaker: Mr CASEY
Text: Th e Australian Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's attitude towards Dutch New

Speaker: NA
Text: Guinea has been frequently the subject

Speaker: NA
Text: of precise and distinct expression by me,

Speaker: NA
Text: on behalf of the Government, the last

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion, I think, being in a chapter of

Speaker: NA
Text: a book which I wrote and published only

Speaker: NA
Text: a few months ago, which dealt with, I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe, every point of view on this matter,

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope, in a fair way. On many occasions

Speaker: NA
Text: previous to that one, I had stated, on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of the Government, Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: view of the matter. I said on these occa-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions that it was the clear and distinct

Speaker: NA
Text: view of the Australian Government that

Speaker: NA
Text: sovereignty in Dutch New Guinea resides

Speaker: NA
Text: .in the Government of the Netherlands.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n saying so, I expressed, and still

Speaker: NA
Text: express the firm opinion of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and the opinion of the whole of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian people, as frequently

Speaker: NA
Text: reflected in the press when this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: becomes a live issue. I fail to see that

Speaker: NA
Text: any good purpose could be served by this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter being taken to the United Nations,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I think I forecast the attitude of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government by saying that we shall resist

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter being included in the agenda

Speaker: NA
Text: for the forthcoming meeting of the

Speaker: NA
Text: General Assembly. However, it may be

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond Australia's power to prevent it

Speaker: NA
Text: from being discussed at the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations. I f and when it is discussed we

Speaker: NA
Text: shall again, with force but, I hope, with-

Speaker: NA
Text: out heat, express our view of it. Dutch

Speaker: NA
Text: New Guinea is of very great strategic

Speaker: NA
Text: importance to Australia. We believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: the legal facts of the case, going right

Speaker: NA
Text: back to the sittings of the round table

Speaker: NA
Text: conference a number of years ago, are

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Dutch made their position com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely clear and that Dutch New Guinea

Speaker: NA
Text: was excluded from what was then the

Speaker: NA
Text: Netherlands East Indies, in connexion

Speaker: NA
Text: with the transfer of the sovereignty of

Speaker: NA
Text: those islands from the Dutch to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Indonesians. However, I do not wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: canvass, in answer to a question, or even

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt to canvass, everything that could

Speaker: NA
Text: be said about this issue. I think one

Speaker: NA
Text: could say, without any disrespect to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Indonesian Government, that the inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ests of the native population would be

Speaker: NA
Text: very much better served under Dutch

Speaker: NA
Text: administration than under Indonesian

Speaker: NA
Text: administration. I hasten to add

Speaker: NA
Text: that I express that opinion without

Speaker: NA
Text: intending disrespect to the Indonesian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. I base i t on the existence

Speaker: NA
Text: of the great series of problems with which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Indonesian Government is faced

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout its territory.

Speaker: Mr HAYLEN
Text: I direct to the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister a question on Dutch New

Speaker: NA
Text: .Guinea that is supplementary to the

Speaker: NA
Text: question addressed to the Minister

Speaker: NA

Text: Guinea, pointing out that the Australian

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: of Alaska and Florida, payment to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dutch to be made in goods and services

Speaker: NA
Text: for the rehabilitation of the East Indies?

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: I appreciate and

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome the Opposition's new-found

Speaker: NA
Text: solicitude for the position of the Dutch.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member's question is sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: plementary to one addressed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for External Affairs, who

Speaker: NA
Text: repeatedly has stated the Australian Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment's attitude in unequivocal terms.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Cabinet entirely subscribes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: statement my right honorable colleague

Speaker: NA
Text: has made.

Speaker: NA
Text: tice to persons whom a Supreme Court

Speaker: NA

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: I do not know

Text: Wha t does the right

Speaker: NA

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: I f I said everything

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of this bill is to make it

Text: -easier for the resident pastoralist in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Territory to obtain credit for

Speaker: NA
Text: the development of his property. The bill

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has been taking both to

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the development of the resources of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory is accompanied by an increase

Speaker: NA
Text: in the number of permanent residents

Speaker: NA
Text: establishing their homes and their families

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Territory.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the earliest steps which the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment took in that direction was to

Speaker: NA
Text: amend the land tenure system in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Territory so as to give a more

Speaker: NA
Text: favorable tenure to the resident owner.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are hoping that, as a result of th«i

Speaker: NA
Text: passage of the Crown Lands Ordinance

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Northern Territory, pastoralists

Speaker: NA
Text: will convert their leaseholds to the form of

Speaker: NA
Text: perpetual leasehold known as the pastoral

Speaker: NA
Text: homestead lease. We are also hoping

Speaker: NA
Text: that, as more land becomes available for

Speaker: NA
Text: application in the Northern Territory, we

Speaker: NA
Text: may be able to attract to the Territory

Speaker: NA
Text: .young, energetic and practical people who

Speaker: NA
Text: will -make the Territory their home. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: order to promote that objective, we not

Speaker: NA
Text: only have to make the land available but

Speaker: NA
Text: we also should try to see that those "who

Speaker: NA
Text: obtain the pastoral homestead leaseholds

Speaker: NA
Text: will have the capital resources necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: to develop them.

Speaker: NA
Text: A cattle station in the Northern Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory -requires a large capital expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: spread over a number of years in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring -it -into a full state of economic

Speaker: NA
Text: development. There may be differences of

Speaker: NA
Text: opinion as to the amount of capitalization

Speaker: NA
Text: which it is economic for a pastoral pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: perty to bear, and the figure varies con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderably from property to property

Speaker: NA
Text: according to such factors as the type of

Speaker: NA
Text: country, access to markets, the type of

Speaker: NA
Text: cattle which can be turned on, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: price likely to be received. As a broad

Speaker: NA
Text: indication to the House of the sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure that is involved, I may men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that some cattle stations of moderate

Speaker: NA
Text: size in tbe Northern Territory carry a

Speaker: NA
Text: capital expenditure, spread over a num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of years, up to £120,000. Expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture is required on the provision of

Speaker: NA
Text: waters at a cost of possibly £4,000 each,

Speaker: NA
Text: some miles of fencing at a cost up to

Speaker: NA
Text: £400 a mile, homestead, staff quarters and

Speaker: NA
Text: other station buildings at a bare mini-

Speaker: NA
Text: mum cost of £15,000, and the building

Speaker: NA
Text: -of yards and dips, quite apart from expen-

Speaker: NA
Text: diture on the herd.

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadly speaking, there is not a great

Speaker: NA
Text: number of young settlers who have that

Speaker: NA
Text: kind of capital at their disposal. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: many cases their assets are their know-

Speaker: NA
Text: ledge, their physical stamina and their

Speaker: NA
Text: pioneering spirit, plus enough capital to

Speaker: NA
Text: acquire a herd of a few thousand head

Speaker: NA
Text: and to give them their first dwelling. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: they go on to new land, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: provides the first two Waters for them so

Speaker: NA
Text: that they can move their cattle on to the

Speaker: NA
Text: run straight away. Most of those who

Speaker: NA
Text: go on to properties, either new or de-

Speaker: NA
Text: veloped, find themselves limited in the

Speaker: NA
Text: early developmental period by the need

Speaker: NA
Text: for more capital. To some extent they

Speaker: NA
Text: can obtain finance through the existing

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions, but their leaseholds are sel-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom accepted as security for ah amount

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient, in the early stages of develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, to make progress possible and, if

Speaker: NA
Text: they give a lien over their stock, the terms

Speaker: NA
Text: are seldom sufficient to do more than meet

Speaker: NA
Text: their running expenses as an offset to

Speaker: NA
Text: their anticipated sales in each year.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n any land development, while the need

Speaker: NA
Text: for capital is clear, i t is also necessary to

Speaker: NA
Text: watch carefully against two unintended

Speaker: NA
Text: results that could impair the final good

Speaker: NA
Text: result. One is the possibility of over-

Speaker: NA
Text: capitalization, or the spending of more on

Speaker: NA
Text: the land than the prospective returns from

Speaker: NA
Text: the land would justify. I t is necessary to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that .expenditure on a property

Speaker: NA
Text: will give an economic return. The other

Speaker: NA
Text: is the possibility that, if credit is too easily

Speaker: NA
Text: obtainable, there will be an inflation of

Speaker: NA
Text: land values, which will also tend, over the

Speaker: NA
Text: years, to impede the economic use of the

Speaker: NA
Text: land. Thus, the administrative problem

Speaker: NA
Text: before the Government is to make credit

Speaker: NA
Text: available for the development of lease-

Speaker: NA
Text: holds, and, at the same time, to see that

Speaker: NA
Text: the availability of credit is closely related

Speaker: NA
Text: to all other factors. After careful con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration, tbe Government also decided

Speaker: NA
Text: that tbe existing financial institutions

Speaker: NA
Text: should be used, that i t was neither neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary nor desirable to establish any new-

Speaker: NA
Text: governmental instrumentality to achieve

Speaker: NA
Text: its purpose or to serve the needs of the

Speaker: NA
Text: prospective beneficiaries under the scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Northern Territory. The bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore, proposes to add to the credit

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities available to settlers of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Territory by providing a

Speaker: NA
Text: guarantee to 'the bank's for advances

Speaker: NA
Text: additional to those which banks might

Speaker: NA
Text: be expected to make in the ordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: course of business and in the absence of

Speaker: NA
Text: a guarantee from the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasury. I n the definitions clause of the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill it is made clear that all banks doing

Speaker: NA
Text: this class of business can assist in the

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme. The upper limit of advances

Speaker: NA
Text: will be the value of leases plus permanent

Speaker: NA
Text: improvements, or a total of £30,000,

Speaker: NA
Text: whichever is the lesser. I n effect, tbis

Speaker: NA
Text: means that a lease-holder will be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: obtain credit up to 100 per cent, of the

Speaker: NA
Text: value of his security, exclusive of his

Speaker: NA
Text: herd, subject to the provision that his

Speaker: NA
Text: total advance, at any time, shall not

Speaker: NA
Text: exceed £30,000. I n the absence of a

Speaker: NA
Text: guarantee, the banks customarily grant

Speaker: NA
Text: credit only up to about 60 per cent, of the

Speaker: NA
Text: value of the security.

Speaker: NA
Text: The best way for me to illustrate to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House how the scheme will operate is to

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hasluck.

Speaker: NA
Text: take three examples from successive stages

Speaker: NA
Text: in the development of leaseholds. I f a

Speaker: NA
Text: lease were in a relatively early stage of

Speaker: NA
Text: development, and the land and permanent

Speaker: NA
Text: improvements were valued at £20,000, a

Speaker: NA
Text: bank might be expected, in the normal

Speaker: NA
Text: course of business, to advance £12,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Treasury will guarantee a further

Speaker: NA
Text: advance of £8,000, making available to

Speaker: NA
Text: the lease-holder a total credit of £20,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f the lease had been developed to a

Speaker: NA
Text: stage where the land plus permanent

Speaker: NA
Text: improvements were valued at £30,000, the

Speaker: NA
Text: bank might be expected to advance

Speaker: NA
Text: £18,000. The Treasury will guarantee

Speaker: NA
Text: a further advance of £12,000, making a

Speaker: NA
Text: total credit of £30,000 available to the

Speaker: NA
Text: lease-holder for developmental purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f the lease had reached a stage of

Speaker: NA
Text: development where the land plus per-

Speaker: NA
Text: manent improvements were valued at.

Speaker: NA
Text: £60,000, a bank might, in the normal

Speaker: NA
Text: course of business, be expected to advance,

Speaker: NA
Text: without guarantee, up to £36,000, i f its

Speaker: NA
Text: omcers were convinced that the property

Speaker: NA
Text: warranted such further expenditure.

Speaker: NA
Text: From these examples honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers will see that the aim of the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill is that the Treasury shall back

Speaker: NA
Text: settlers until they can stand on

Speaker: NA
Text: their own financial feet and that the

Speaker: NA
Text: normal methods of obtaining credit will

Speaker: NA
Text: then be followed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill provides that guaranteed

Speaker: NA
Text: advances may be made for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of effecting permanent im-

Speaker: NA
Text: provements to land the subject of

Speaker: NA
Text: leases, or partly for that purpose

Speaker: NA
Text: and partly for the purpose of discharging

Speaker: NA
Text: prior encumbrances in order to enable

Speaker: NA
Text: new first mortgages to be given as

Speaker: NA
Text: security. I n other words, the bill will

Speaker: NA
Text: help a lease-holder so to improve his posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion as to be able to obtain credit in the

Speaker: NA
Text: normal way. I t should induce a consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: able increase of the amount of credit

Speaker: NA
Text: available in the Northern Territory. The

Speaker: NA
Text: increase will be probably far greater

Speaker: NA
Text: than the amount actually guaranteed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth. The granting of

Speaker: NA
Text: advances to pastoralists for purposes

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned in the bill should be-

Speaker: NA
Text: come more attractive to the banks

Speaker: NA
Text: than' in the past. Therefore, the measure

Speaker: NA
Text: should stimulate their interest in the

Speaker: NA
Text: development of the Northern Territory

Speaker: NA
Text: and reduce the conservatism that they

Speaker: NA
Text: have previously evinced in the making

Speaker: NA
Text: of advances to settlers. I t is confidently

Speaker: NA
Text: expected that the bill will be instru-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental in bringing about a considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: improvement of the standard of pastoral

Speaker: NA
Text: properties. By this measure the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is demonstrating its confidence in

Speaker: NA
Text: the future of the Northern Territory.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is hoped that this will stimulate the

Speaker: NA
Text: interest of business institutions in that

Speaker: NA
Text: development. The Government has had

Speaker: NA
Text: no direct experience of this kind of assistready

Speaker: NA
Text: a n t to settlers in the Northern Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory, and consequently we shall watch

Speaker: NA
Text: very closely the application of the provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions of the bill. I f necessary, in future,

Speaker: NA
Text: other steps will" be taken to help to ensure export.

Speaker: NA
Text: that the measures are adequate to achieve

Speaker: NA
Text: the result desired. The scheme can be

Speaker: NA
Text: adjusted to meet new needs or new oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunities. At the same time it must

Speaker: NA
Text: be watched closely. Although we want to

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage development, we do not want

Speaker: NA
Text: to reach that stage of careless expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: and financial light-heartedness as a pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: lude to financial misery which charac-

Speaker: NA
Text: terized some of the earlier scheme of

Speaker: NA
Text: assisted settlement in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The conditions that I have mentioned

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to pastoral homestead leases

Speaker: NA
Text: will apply, also, to agricultural leases in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Northern Territory. The limits to

Speaker: NA
Text: agriculture in the Territory are deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mined not only by the fact that most of

Speaker: NA
Text: the land is in a low rainfall area, but

Speaker: NA
Text: that, in the areas of relatively higher

Speaker: NA
Text: rainfall, normally regarded as most suit-

Speaker: NA
Text: able for agriculture, there is every year a

Speaker: NA
Text: rainless period of seven or eight months.

Speaker: NA
Text: Only a few rivers in the Northern Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory carry enough water to enable the

Speaker: NA
Text: establishment of irrigation schemes,

Speaker: NA
Text: within the conventional meaning of the

Speaker: NA
Text: term. I n view of this seasonal situation,

Speaker: NA
Text: our problem is to find the crops that can

Speaker: NA
Text: be raised profitably in the Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory. During the last three years

Speaker: NA
Text: much new work-totall y new, as far as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Territory is concerned-ha s been

Speaker: NA
Text: carried out under the direction of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Administrator, Mr "Wise, in experiment-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing with various crops under field condi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. For a number of years, also, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Administration and tbe Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Scientific and Industrial Besearch

Speaker: NA
Text: Organization have co-operated in various

Speaker: NA
Text: experiments and trials at the Katherine

Speaker: NA
Text: experiment farm. More recently, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have begun investigations into water

Speaker: NA
Text: supplies, the best way of using the avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able water, and the problem of water con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol in the higher rainfall areas near

Speaker: NA
Text: Darwin. Those studies are continuing.

Speaker: NA
Text: With the help of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Scientific and Industrial Besearch

Speaker: NA
Text: Organization, extensive soil surveys have

Speaker: NA
Text: been carried out. Most of the soils with

Speaker: NA
Text: possible agricultural value have been al-

Speaker: NA
Text: mapped, with a good deal of exact-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness. I n addition, a few pioneer settlers

Speaker: NA
Text: have embarked on the production of food-

Speaker: NA
Text: stuffs for local consumption and, to a

Speaker: NA
Text: limited extent, bananas and peanuts for

Speaker: NA
Text: The credit facilities provided by the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: will be available not only to the existing

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers in the Northern Territory, but

Speaker: NA
Text: also to persons who, as a result of the

Speaker: NA
Text: experimental work that is being carried

Speaker: NA
Text: out by the Government, may be en-

Speaker: NA
Text: couraged to enter the agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: industry in the Territory.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n passing, although it is not related to

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill, I might point out tbat, for some

Speaker: NA
Text: time, a scheme of advances to primary pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers-mostl y small men growing fresh

Speaker: NA
Text: foodstuffs in the vicinity of Darwin-ha s

Speaker: NA
Text: been administered locally by a primary

Speaker: NA
Text: producers' board. Hitherto, the limit of

Speaker: NA
Text: advances by the board has been £600 to

Speaker: NA
Text: also each settler. The Government has decided

Speaker: NA
Text: to raise that Hmit to £3,000. The purpose

Speaker: NA
Text: of the scheme administered by the board

Speaker: NA
Text: is mainly to assist small producers to

Speaker: NA
Text: obtain implements and equipment. That

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme is quite different from the scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: envisaged in the bill and was created to

Speaker: NA
Text: serve a different purpose.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n order that tbe propsals in this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill may be seen in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: background it might interest the

Speaker: NA
Text: House I f I were to indicate, broadly the

Speaker: NA
Text: present scope of the pastoral and agri-

Speaker: NA
Text: cultural industries in the Northern Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory. They are far more extensive than is

Speaker: NA
Text: generally recognized by persons living in

Speaker: NA
Text: the southern States. Cattle are produced

Speaker: NA
Text: on 407 pastoral leases having a total area

Speaker: NA
Text: of 215,355 square miles. Not acres, mind

Speaker: NA
Text: you, but square miles. At first scrutiny,

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately 318 of those leases would

Speaker: NA
Text: appear to be held in a way that might

Speaker: NA
Text: qualify, them for' conversion to pastoral,

Speaker: NA
Text: homestead leases; with perpetual tenure;,

Speaker: NA
Text: aud about. 89 held by companies would!

Speaker: NA
Text: qualify for conversion to leases with a

Speaker: NA
Text: 50-year tenure. Definite improvement

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions w i ll be written into all. new

Speaker: NA
Text: leases granted under the. Crown Land

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordinances. I t is expected that some

Speaker: NA
Text: lease-holders may surrender areas on

Speaker: NA
Text: which they expect thait. they will be

Speaker: NA
Text: unable to maintain the required level

Speaker: NA
Text: of improvements. As an example of the

Speaker: NA
Text: way the policy will be applied

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Northern Territory, I refer honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ablemembers to the statement that 1

Speaker: NA
Text: made in the House on the 7th April, when

Speaker: NA
Text: I pointed out that Vestey's, in negotiating

Speaker: NA
Text: new leases under the new ordinances, had

Speaker: NA
Text: surrendered 8,493 square miles of lease-

Speaker: NA
Text: hold,, and 5,351 square miles held under

Speaker: NA
Text: grazing licence and had accepted improve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment conditions on their remaining leases

Speaker: NA
Text: in tlie form of firm obligations with

Speaker: NA
Text: specific requirements that they make an

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure of £250,000 during the next

Speaker: NA
Text: fi ve years.

Speaker: NA
Text: On all the Territory holdings there is

Speaker: NA
Text: a cattle population of a little over

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,000,000 head and an average annual

Speaker: NA
Text: turn-off of 115,000 head, some going

Speaker: NA
Text: straight to the meatworks and some going

Speaker: NA
Text: as stores, mainly to Queensland. The

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated annual value is about

Speaker: NA
Text: £2y720,000. I n spite of a most severe and

Speaker: NA
Text: widespread drought in 1951-52 and some

Speaker: NA
Text: rather indifferent seasons since in some

Speaker: NA
Text: parts of the Territory, tbe cattle industry

Speaker: NA
Text: is progressing. The approximate turn-off

Speaker: NA
Text: over the past seven years has totalled

Speaker: NA
Text: 800,000 head and the annual turn-off has

Speaker: NA
Text: varied, between 146,000 in a good yeai*

Speaker: NA
Text: and S1,000 in a bad, the turn-off

Speaker: NA
Text: necessarily fluctuating according to

Speaker: NA
Text: seasonal conditions. I t is estimated that

Speaker: NA
Text: in the past four years there has been a.

Speaker: NA
Text: private investment in improvements on

Speaker: NA
Text: cattle stations in the Northern Territory

Speaker: NA
Text: of more than £1,000,000- a heartening

Speaker: NA
Text: sign of the confidence of cattlemen in

Speaker: NA
Text: the future of the country tliey occupy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's own officers estimate

Speaker: NA
Text: that the potential for development, of the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry is an increase of about 50 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, in the carrying capacity of land

Speaker: NA
Text: already occupied and a doubling of the

Speaker: NA
Text: annual turn-off. We believe that that

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Basluoh.

Speaker: NA
Text: improvement cantake place without any.

Speaker: NA
Text: revolutionary change in the traditional;

Speaker: NA
Text: methods of raisingcattle in the Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory. I f , by one means or another,

Speaker: NA
Text: through the aid of science, completely

Speaker: NA
Text: different methods were to be developed-

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Northern Territory, the change

Speaker: NA
Text: may be even greater.

Speaker: NA
Text: The present state of agricul-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture is that production of food-

Speaker: NA
Text: stuffs, such as vegetables and eggs, i.;

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken on a small scale, for local con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumption, and, as I have said , some fruit

Speaker: NA
Text: and peanut production is undertaken for

Speaker: NA
Text: export to southern Australian, markets.

Speaker: NA
Text: The potential development that is in

Speaker: NA
Text: sight is large-scale rice-growing, a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderable expansion of peanut cultiva-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion ancl establishment of tobacco-growing.

Speaker: NA
Text: These look like being our main export

Speaker: NA
Text: possibilities. I t also includes the estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lishment of mixed farming for the sake

Speaker: NA
Text: of local food supply and as an adjunct

Speaker: NA
Text: to stock raising. However, continued'

Speaker: NA
Text: experimentation is necessary to demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: strate with reasonable certainty farm sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tems which can be applied to the land

Speaker: NA
Text: with reasonable prospects of providing »

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfactory living for the farmers.

Speaker: NA
Text: .hi conclusion, I stress that the only way

Speaker: NA
Text: in which any of our visions of progress in

Speaker: NA
Text: the north can be realized-an d I think

Speaker: NA
Text: most honorable members have a vision of

Speaker: NA
Text: progress there-i s through the efforts of

Speaker: NA
Text: individual settlers. The end of govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment policy, as exemplified by this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: and by other measures, is to help tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: individual Australian i n the Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Torritory to do his job for the nation in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Northern Territory. That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of the attempts we have made

Speaker: NA
Text: and will continue to make to improve the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic services of education, health and

Speaker: NA
Text: communications and to add to the

Speaker: NA
Text: amenities of life, so that people can live

Speaker: NA
Text: at a proper standard i n the Territory.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is also the purpose of the. various

Speaker: NA
Text: investigations and experiments we are

Speaker: NA
Text: carrying, out into tbe ways in whicb

Speaker: NA
Text: people can earn a living, in tie Territory.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the purpose of our revision of

Speaker: NA
Text: the land laws. I t is tlie purpose behind

Speaker: NA
Text: the increased provision we have made to

Speaker: NA
Text: assist various industries, for example, by

Speaker: NA
Text: the veterinary services, the stock routes

Speaker: NA
Text: and roads which are being provided f o r

Speaker: NA
Text: the pastoral industry. I t is the purpose

Speaker: NA
Text: behind our attempts to encourage a new

Speaker: NA
Text: idea of the standard of living in the

Speaker: NA
Text: tropics, as exemplified by the housing

Speaker: NA
Text: and community services constructed by

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory Enterprises at Batchelor. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: is to the purpose of a relatively small

Speaker: NA
Text: measure sueh as the present bill. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: people believe that settlers who go to

Speaker: NA
Text: live in the Northern Territory ought to

Speaker: NA
Text: live in humpies. Those days are past.

Speaker: NA
Text: The nation, has to accept the idea that the

Speaker: NA
Text: people in the Northern. Territory are to

Speaker: NA
Text: live in good homes at a standard of living

Speaker: NA
Text: comparable with the best standards

Speaker: NA
Text: enjoyed by people anywhere in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: We hope that this bill will make it more

Speaker: NA
Text: easily possible for the residents of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory to develop the land that they

Speaker: NA
Text: can obtain, and make their contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: to the progress of the Territory. We

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that the Northern Territory, like

Speaker: NA
Text: any other part of Australia, will grow by

Speaker: NA
Text: tha efforts o'f its people. Tbe role of

Speaker: NA
Text: government, in the liberal view, is to help

Speaker: NA
Text: the people to get on with the job. I trust

Speaker: NA
Text: that this bill will serve that purpose in

Speaker: NA
Text: the pastoral and agricultural industries

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Northern Territory and, in thar,

Speaker: NA
Text: faith, commend it to tbe House.

Speaker: Mr NEI
Text: .SON)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Text: BILL 1954.

Text: Motion (by Mr HASLUCK) agreed to-

Speaker: NA
Text: That leave be given to bring in a ibill for

Speaker: NA
Text: aet to amend the Papua and New Guinea Act

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill presented', and road a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: SECOND BBADINO.

Speaker: Mr HASLUCK
Text: Ourtin-Ministe r for

Speaker: NA
Text: Territories) [4.2] - I move-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the bill be now read a second time.
