Text: Under this bill i t is proposed to make

Speaker: NA
Text: several small amendments to the Papua

Speaker: NA
Text: and New Guinea Act, which was passed

Speaker: NA
Text: by this Parliament in 1949 to provide for

Speaker: NA
Text: theadministration of the Territory of

Speaker: NA
Text: Papua and the Territory of New Guinea

Speaker: NA
Text: in an administrative union. Only two of

Speaker: NA
Text: tho amendments involve'decisions on any

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of substance. I t is proposed to

Speaker: NA
Text: amend section 73 of the principal act i n

Speaker: NA
Text: order to make it clear that the'prerogative

Speaker: NA
Text: of mercy is exercised by the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General. Section 73, as it stands, confers

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Administrator of the Territory

Speaker: NA
Text: power to grant to any offender convicted

Speaker: NA
Text: by a court exercising criminal jurisdic-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in the Territory, a pardon, either

Speaker: NA
Text: free or conditional, or a remission or

Speaker: NA
Text: commutation of sentence, or a respite for

Speaker: NA
Text: such period as he thinks fit, of the execu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of sentence. The Government con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siders, and I am sure the House will agree,

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is inappropriate for an oflicial to

Speaker: NA
Text: be required to exercise such powers in

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to a sentence of death. A sen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tence of death is clearly in a wholly

Speaker: NA
Text: different category from a sentence of

Speaker: NA
Text: imprisonment and, whereas we see no

Speaker: NA
Text: objection to the Administrator, who is a

Speaker: NA
Text: government official, continuing to have

Speaker: NA
Text: the authority to remit or commute sen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tences that involve lesser penalties, we do

Speaker: NA
Text: not think the prerogative of mercy should

Speaker: NA
Text: be exercised except at the very highest

Speaker: NA
Text: levels of government. Some time ago an

Speaker: NA
Text: instruction to that effect was given to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Administrator by the Government and

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill, giving effect to administrative

Speaker: NA
Text: practice over the past three years, will

Speaker: NA
Text: exclude death sentences from the section

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with the Administrator's powers

Speaker: NA
Text: and will insert a new sub-section as

Speaker: NA
Text: follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Governor-General may, by warrant

Speaker: NA
Text: under his hand, grant to an offender sentenced

Speaker: NA
Text: to death by a court exercising criminal juris-

Speaker: NA
Text: diction in the Territory a pardon, either free or

Speaker: NA
Text: an conditional,, or a remission or commutation-

Speaker: NA
Text: of sentence, or a respite for such period as he

Speaker: NA
Text: thinks fit, of the execution of sentence.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f any death sentence, is passed in Papua

Speaker: NA
Text: and New Guinea the procedure will be to

Speaker: NA
Text: refer it to Canberra, where the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General acting in Executive Council will

Speaker: NA
Text: decide whether or not i t is to be carried

Speaker: NA
Text: out. I may mention, i n passing that this

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed amendment, does not arise out

Speaker: NA
Text: of, or have any direct relation to, any

Speaker: NA
Text: recent events in the Territory. The

Speaker: NA
Text: decision was made early last year and,, i n

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, the present bill has been in draft

Speaker: NA
Text: form for many months. I t will, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, be applicable, to any death,

Speaker: NA
Text: sentences recently passed in the Territory,

Speaker: NA
Text: but the idea of presenting this bill to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House did not arise out of any recent

Speaker: NA
Text: incident in the Territory.

Speaker: Mr DUTHIE
Text: Wa s it touched up

Speaker: NA
Text: afterwards ?

Speaker: Mr HASLUCK
Text: No . No change

Speaker: NA
Text: has been made. The bill reads as i t was

Speaker: NA
Text: drafted twelve months ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other substantial decision to which

Speaker: NA
Text: effect is given in this bill, is to change

Speaker: NA
Text: the title of Chief Judge of the Supreme

Speaker: NA
Text: Court of the Territory to Chief Justice.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is in keeping with the usage in the

Speaker: NA
Text: supreme courts of the States of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The change in title is accompanied by

Speaker: NA
Text: a provision to appoint the present Chief

Speaker: NA
Text: Judge, Mr Justice Phillips, as Chief

Speaker: NA
Text: Justice with continuity of office.

Speaker: NA
Text: As it was necessary to introduce an

Speaker: NA
Text: amending bill to make the changes

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned above, advantage was taken

Speaker: NA
Text: of the opportunity to make other minor

Speaker: NA
Text: changes the need for which had become

Speaker: NA
Text: apparent in the working of the principal

Speaker: NA
Text: act. A l l references to native village

Speaker: NA
Text: councils in the principal act will be

Speaker: NA
Text: replaced by the words "native local

Speaker: NA
Text: government councils", because, in prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tice, the majority of councils established

Speaker: NA
Text: have not been set up in relation to indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: vidual villages but have been formed to

Speaker: NA
Text: represent several groups of villages. No

Speaker: NA
Text: change will be made in respect of the

Speaker: NA
Text: nature and functions of these councils.

Speaker: NA
Text: An amendment is proposed to clause

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 to enable an official member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislative Council to resign his seat.

Speaker: NA
Text: Previously i f an official member wished

Speaker: NA
Text: to resign for any reason whatsoever there

Speaker: NA
Text: was no legal provision by which he could

Speaker: NA
Text: do so. The resignation will not, however,

Speaker: NA
Text: become effective unless and until accepted

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Governor-General, by whom the

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment of official members is made

Speaker: NA
Text: and subject to whose pleasure such

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments are held. A further amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will also make i t clear that resignalonger

Speaker: NA
Text: tion by a non-official member becomes

Speaker: NA
Text: effective when it is received by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Administrator. These proposed amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments are similar to amendments made

Speaker: NA
Text: during 1953 to the Northern Territory

Speaker: NA
Text: .(Administration) Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: Section 52 of the Papua and New

Speaker: NA
Text: Guinea Act requires that certain

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinances of the Legislative Council

Speaker: NA
Text: Papua and New Guinea shall be reserved

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Governor-General's pleasure,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Governor-General has power only.to

Speaker: NA
Text: s BiU 1954.

Speaker: NA
Text: assent or withhold assent to the ordinance

Speaker: NA
Text: in its entirety. Instances have occurred

Speaker: NA
Text: where it would have been of advantage

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Governor-General to be able tc

Speaker: NA
Text: withhold assent to part, only, of an

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinance. I n the absence of such

Speaker: NA
Text: power, it has been necessary for assent to

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole of an ordinance to be withheld

Speaker: NA
Text: when part only of it was not acceptable.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clause 11 of the bill proposes an amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment which will enable the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General to assent either to the whole or

Speaker: NA
Text: part of an ordinance reserved for his

Speaker: NA
Text: pleasure. The new section departs from

Speaker: NA
Text: the existing section by providing that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor-General's declaration as to

Speaker: NA
Text: assent or otherwise, and not the Gazette

Speaker: NA
Text: notification, must take place within one

Speaker: NA
Text: year and also that, i f the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General's assent is not to be given, lie

Speaker: NA
Text: shall expressly declare that he withholds

Speaker: NA
Text: assent. The first departure is intended

Speaker: NA
Text: to avoid the difficulties that could arise

Speaker: NA
Text: as to pnblication within twelve months

Speaker: NA
Text: if assent were not given until near the

Speaker: NA
Text: end of the expiration of that period. The

Speaker: NA
Text: second departure is to enable the Gover-

Speaker: NA
Text: nor-General to declare forthwith that he

Speaker: NA
Text: withholds assent to an Ordinance and

Speaker: NA
Text: thus avoid the uncertainty as to his

Speaker: NA
Text: intention that would otherwise exist until

Speaker: NA
Text: the period of one year has elapsed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Consequent on the inauguration of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislative Council for Papua and New

Speaker: NA
Text: Guinea it was clear that that part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: principal act relating to the interim legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lative powers of the Governor-General

Speaker: NA
Text: was unnecessary. I t is now possible to

Speaker: NA
Text: repeal the whole of the division of the

Speaker: NA
Text: act relating to the interim legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: powers of the Governor-General. As

Speaker: NA
Text: laws are now made by the Legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: Council, the need for these provisions no

Speaker: NA
Text: exists. Appropriate provision is

Speaker: NA
Text: contained in the bill to ensure the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinuance in force of all ordinances made

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Governor-General during such

Speaker: NA
Text: interim period which still remain in

Speaker: NA
Text: force, as well as to provide enabling

Speaker: NA
Text: power for the Legislative Council to

Speaker: NA
Text: amend or repeal such ordinances as the

Speaker: NA
Text: necessity may arise from time to time.

Speaker: NA
Text: for I repeat tbat only two decisions on

Speaker: NA
Text: matters of substance are involved in this

Speaker: NA
Text: but bill. Tbe other amendments may

Speaker: NA
Text: properly be described as tidying-up

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments, designed to make the present

Speaker: NA
Text: act clearer and more easily workable.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr CHAMBERS)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: GOVERNOR-GENERAL'S SPEECH.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADDBESS - IN - REPL Y.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 10th August,

Speaker: NA
Text: (vide page 122), on motion by Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: LINDSAY-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the following Address-in-Keply to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Speech of His Excellency the Governor-General

Speaker: NA
Text: be agreed to: -

Speaker: NA
Text: MAY IT Pt.EASE Y'OUIS EXCEI.LEKCY:

Speaker: NA
Text: We, the House of Eepresentatives of the

Speaker: NA
Text: farliament of the Commonwealth of Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: in Parliament assembled, desire to express our

Speaker: NA
Text: loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign, and

Speaker: NA
Text: to thank Your Excellency for the Speech which

Speaker: NA
Text: you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

Speaker: Mr CURTIN
Text: Watson) [4.12] -

Speaker: NA
Text: Wben tbis debate was adjourned I was

Speaker: NA
Text: pressing the Government to pay some

Speaker: NA
Text: attention to the very controversial subject

Speaker: NA
Text: of margins for skill. The trade union

Speaker: NA
Text: movement has made up its mind that

Speaker: NA
Text: what was tolerable during the imme-

Speaker: NA
Text: diate post-war period is no longer

Speaker: NA
Text: tolerable. The long-suffering trades-

Speaker: NA
Text: men are becoming uneasy at the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: crastination of the gentlemen of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Arbitration Court. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government does not take action

Speaker: NA
Text: quickly in relation to margins for skill,

Speaker: NA
Text: very grave industrial unrest will occur

Speaker: NA
Text: and the blame will be laid at the door

Speaker: NA
Text: of this incompetent Government - The

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Menzies) has indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated that the Government will under-

Speaker: NA
Text: take large defence expenditure. This

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure will require much technical

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment and we shall need more techni-

Speaker: NA
Text: cians to operate that equipment. Where

Speaker: NA
Text: does the Prime Minister think that he

Speaker: NA
Text: will get tbe technicians to do essential

Speaker: NA
Text: work in connexion with the defence pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gramme? The Government has negated

Speaker: NA
Text: all claims for simple justice by skilled

Speaker: NA
Text: workers. I t bas killed the incentive that

Speaker: NA
Text: the average lad needs to induce him to

Speaker: NA
Text: embark on a career as a skilled tradesman.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government should give deep con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration to this subject when it is con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidering its defence programme. We must

Speaker: NA
Text: not forget the position in which we were

Speaker: NA
Text: left when war broke out in 1939. A l l

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of committees had to be set up in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to find men with varying degrees

Speaker: NA
Text: of skill to carry on tbe work that was

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary at that time. Recently, the

Speaker: NA
Text: secretary of the Brisbane branch of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Boilermakers TJnion made the following

Speaker: NA
Text: statement in court:-

Speaker: NA
Text: Two hundred boilermakers are needed in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland . . . We have had appeals

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Eailways Department and private

Speaker: NA
Text: industry to recruit staff for them. I n one

Speaker: NA
Text: instance alone, a private employer in Brisbane

Speaker: NA
Text: could place more than 100 boilermakers. One

Speaker: NA
Text: of the prime factors in the shortage was lack

Speaker: NA
Text: of inducement for lads to enter the trade as

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices.

Speaker: NA
Text: The shortage had caused a considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of overtime work and to protect the

Speaker: NA
Text: health of members, the society had limited

Speaker: NA
Text: overtime to twelve hours a week.

Speaker: NA
Text: That assertion was replied to by the secre-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary of the Queensland Employers' Fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: said-

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no trut h in thc suggestion that

Speaker: NA
Text: boilermakers were scarce because of a lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: inducement to youths to enter the trade . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: He added-

Speaker: NA
Text: I u dealings with 'unions our experience has

Speaker: NA
Text: been that youths and men w i l l avoid a trade

Speaker: NA
Text: where union leaders regularly call stoppages

Speaker: NA
Text: and strikes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Such a statement shows that this

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman is unfit to hold the posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that he occupies. Apprentices

Speaker: NA
Text: are not allowed to strike, and unions place

Speaker: NA
Text: severe restrictions on apprentices in that

Speaker: NA
Text: regard. Mr Self continued-

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead, they prefer continuity of work in

Speaker: NA
Text: a trade which is not upset by union leaders.

Speaker: NA
Text: All trade unions have leaders, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: people who employ Mr Self to give his

Speaker: NA
Text: opinions in regard to incentives sbould

Speaker: NA
Text: seriously consider removing him from his

Speaker: NA
Text: position because his statements are very

Speaker: NA
Text: provocative indeed. The Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour and National Service ( Mr Holt),

Speaker: NA
Text: in a speech that he delivered on the 29th

Speaker: NA
Text: June about margins for skill, said that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government would support claims for

Speaker: NA
Text: higher margins for really skilled men, as

Speaker: NA
Text: long as they were not submerged in a

Speaker: NA
Text: general claim for higher margins for all

Speaker: NA
Text: workers. Of course, he was just creating

Speaker: NA
Text: a smoke-screen in order to set up some

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of caste system among skilled workers.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f the Minister had taken sufficient trouble

Speaker: NA
Text: to analyse the quality of the skills pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sessed by many workers, he would not

Speaker: NA
Text: have made a statement such as that. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example, no one can doubt tbat a rigger

Speaker: NA
Text: is a highly skilled man. A man needs to

Speaker: NA
Text: have fifteen or twenty years' experience

Speaker: NA
Text: before he can become a fully qualified

Speaker: NA
Text: rigger. The shearer has to use his know-

Speaker: NA
Text: ledge and skill as well as have excellent

Speaker: NA
Text: physical development. The timber-getter,

Speaker: NA
Text: besides being a skilled man, has to take

Speaker: NA
Text: great risks in his occupation. The builder's

Speaker: NA
Text: labourer is a most essential member of

Speaker: NA
Text: the community. The brickmaker, the

Speaker: NA
Text: ironworker, the wharflabourer and the

Speaker: NA
Text: tilemaker are all skilled workmen, and

Speaker: NA
Text: yet the Minister for Labour and National

Speaker: NA
Text: Service apparently does not recognize their

Speaker: NA
Text: skill. I suggest that statements such as

Speaker: NA
Text: that made by the Minister merely pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: voke our trade unions into action.

Speaker: NA
Text: Margins for skill bave not increased since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1945, and skilled workmen are now deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mined to be heard. I f the Justices of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and

Speaker: NA
Text: Arbitration, and the Government, will not.

Speaker: NA
Text: listen to them, they will take some action

Speaker: NA
Text: which will not be to the advantage of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government or the community in general.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr TUHNBDLI. -Wha t action?

Speaker: Mr CURTIN
Text: Le t us be realistic

Speaker: NA
Text: about it. They will threaten to strike

Speaker: NA
Text: and withhold their labour, just as pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: mary producers among the members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Country party withhold

Speaker: NA
Text: their products from the markets. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Country party has claimed

Speaker: NA
Text: that the farmer is justified in withholding

Speaker: NA
Text: his produce when he pleases, and there-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore it must admit that highly skilled

Speaker: NA
Text: workmen are justified in withholding

Speaker: NA
Text: their labour in certain circumstances. Such

Speaker: NA
Text: men, especially those in defence produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion industries, should be looked after by

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government, which should intervene

Speaker: NA
Text: before the court when they make applica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions for increased margins for skill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Shipwrights, engineers, boilermakers and

Speaker: NA
Text: moulders are not going to be trifled with

Speaker: NA
Text: any longer. They intend to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: they shall get a just reward for their

Speaker: NA
Text: skill. Indeed, the Australian Council of

Speaker: NA
Text: Trades Unions has now decided upon a

Speaker: NA
Text: certain policy whicb has been endorsed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Federal Conference of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour party. I am speaking on behalf

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian Council of Trades

Speaker: NA
Text: Unions when I claim that this very im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant matter cannot be trifled with any

Speaker: NA
Text: longer. I f the Government, thinks that

Speaker: NA
Text: it can continue to so trifle with skilled

Speaker: NA
Text: men, it is completely wrong,, At present

Speaker: NA
Text: an industrial pattern is beginning to

Speaker: NA
Text: take shape which is similar to the pattern

Speaker: NA
Text: that was woven before the 1917 upheaval.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Orde r 1 The honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's time has expired.

Speaker: Mr DAVIDSON
Text: Dawson) [4.22] - I

Speaker: NA
Text: was more than amused a few moments

Speaker: NA
Text: ago to hear the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Watson ( Mr Curtin) say that primary

Speaker: NA
Text: producers in the Australian Country

Speaker: NA
Text: party had, from time to time, threatened

Speaker: NA
Text: to withhold their produce from the

Speaker: NA
Text: market. That statement should not be

Speaker: NA
Text: given any serious attention at all, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: can say from long experience, as an active

Speaker: NA
Text: primary producer and as a member of

Speaker: NA
Text: primary producers' organizations, that

Speaker: NA
Text: the statement is quite incorrect. Pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: mary producers are the greatest wealth

Speaker: NA
Text: producers in this country, because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: sale of their products overseas, and they

Speaker: NA
Text: bave too great a sense of responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: for the well-being of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people even to consider withholding their

Speaker: NA
Text: produce. I t is unfortunate that the bodies

Speaker: NA
Text: represented by the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Watson do not have a similar sense of

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: His Excellency, in the Speech that he

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered at the opening of this Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, made two important references to

Speaker: NA
Text: the intention of the Government with

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to national development. First,

Speaker: NA
Text: he said-

Speaker: NA
Text: My Government will closely examine thc

Speaker: NA
Text: extent to which additional transport links,

Speaker: NA
Text: including rail links, are desirable for the

Speaker: NA
Text: development of beef production in north

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland and the Northern Territory.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, he said-

Speaker: NA
Text: In the Territories of the Commonwealth, on

Speaker: NA
Text: the foundations laid in the past three years,

Speaker: NA
Text: further progressmay be confidently expected

Speaker: NA
Text: both in the advancement of the welfare of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people and in the development of resources.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Papua and New Guinea the rate of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestigation and classification of land and \v;:ter

Speaker: NA
Text: resources and agricultural output will be in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased. Expanded services will improve the

Speaker: NA
Text: health, education and social statu:) of the

Speaker: NA
Text: natives.

Speaker: NA
Text: I welcome those two statements, of Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment policy with regard to national

Speaker: NA
Text: development, and I propose to comment

Speaker: NA
Text: on. both of them. The first statement

Speaker: NA
Text: applies to the development, of the northern

Speaker: NA
Text: portion of Australia, which .includes

Speaker: NA
Text: the north-west of Western Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, the northern part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Nor thern Territory and the North-

Speaker: NA
Text: western and northern parts of Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land. That great area of land, which

Speaker: NA
Text: stretches across the north of our con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinent, is very sparsely settled and sadly

Speaker: NA
Text: in need of development. For many years

Speaker: NA
Text: most people have realized that it should

Speaker: NA
Text: be developed, but there has been a lack

Speaker: NA
Text: of positive action in that direction.

Speaker: NA
Text: The result is tbat that great area is still

Speaker: NA
Text: crying aloud for a concerted plan of

Speaker: NA
Text: development by both State and Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: governments. The nation can no longer

Speaker: NA
Text: afford to pay only lip service to the cause

Speaker: NA
Text: of development nor can it rely on

Speaker: NA
Text: spasmodic investigations by committees.

Speaker: NA
Text: We must move rapidly towards the prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tical development of that area-

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is generally known, I think, that

Speaker: NA
Text: main source of wealth and, therefore, the

Speaker: NA
Text: most important factor in the development

Speaker: NA
Text: of this area, is the meat industry. I t is

Speaker: NA
Text: true that mineral discoveries in recent

Speaker: NA
Text: years indicate that there is a certain

Speaker: NA
Text: future for the northern parts of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: in mineral production, and it is also true,

Speaker: NA
Text: as the Minister for Territories ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Hasluck) stated a few moments ago, that

Speaker: NA
Text: the area may be suitable for small farms.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n the main, however, we must apply OUT-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves to the production of beef. A l -

Speaker: NA
Text: though such production has been carried

Speaker: NA
Text: on for many years, the ceiling rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: production was reached, under prevailing

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions, some time ago. We must try

Speaker: NA
Text: to ascertain the reasons for the existence

Speaker: NA
Text: of that ceiling. Immediately we under-

Speaker: NA
Text: take such an investigation, I suggest that

Speaker: NA
Text: the most cogent reason will be found to

Speaker: NA
Text: lie in tbe inadequate transport facilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: His Excellency the Governor-General,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Speech which he made in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House recently, stated that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment had committed itself closely to

Speaker: NA
Text: -examine the extent to which additional

Speaker: NA
Text: transport links, including rail links, were

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary in this area. To my way of

Speaker: NA
Text: -thinking, that was a very important

Speaker: NA
Text: aspect of the Speech. Of course, there

Speaker: NA
Text: are otber factors involved in the failure

Speaker: NA
Text: to expand the beef industry in recent

Speaker: NA
Text: years, but i t seems to me that those factors

Speaker: NA
Text: -are largely associated with agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: and pastoral practice. I t would be idle

Speaker: NA
Text: for us to provide, say, better watering

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities and better management, with a

Speaker: NA
Text: view to increasing beef production, unless

Speaker: NA
Text: we also improved transport facilities,

Speaker: NA
Text: because the provision of the other facili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties to which I have referred would

Speaker: NA
Text: merely serve to accentuate the inadequacy

Speaker: NA
Text: of the transport system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under present conditions, cattlemen

Speaker: NA
Text: are forced to walk their cattle for

Speaker: NA
Text: hundreds of miles before they arrive at

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe rail head. Such journeys are gene-

Speaker: NA
Text: rally through inhospitable and badly-

Speaker: NA
Text: watered country, with the result that the

Speaker: NA
Text: gTaziers are not able to dispose of their

Speaker: NA
Text: stock until they are at least four years'

Speaker: NA
Text: old. Young cattle cannot stand up to the

Speaker: NA
Text: strenuous journeys which are necessary.

Speaker: NA
Text: For that reason, graziers are compelled

Speaker: NA
Text: to keep their stock far beyond the time

Speaker: NA
Text: when they would produce young, good

Speaker: NA
Text: the quality beef. I n addition, even when the

Speaker: NA
Text: stock arrive at the railhead, they still

Speaker: NA
Text: have to face long jolting journeys over

Speaker: NA
Text: rough railway systems. The result of all

Speaker: NA
Text: this is that second quality beef is being

Speaker: NA
Text: produced from that area.

Speaker: NA
Text: The markets available to our heef

Speaker: NA
Text: industry have an important bearing on

Speaker: NA
Text: t.he points I wish to make. There is, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, our home market. One frequently

Speaker: NA
Text: hears criticism by housewives and others

Speaker: NA
Text: that, despite the fact that Australia claims

Speaker: NA
Text: to be one of the major beef-producing

Speaker: NA
Text: countries of the world, the beef they

Speaker: NA
Text: purchase in the butchers' shops is often

Speaker: NA
Text: of very poor quality. Then, we have the

Speaker: NA
Text: market provided for us under the recently

Speaker: NA
Text: arranged contract with Great Britain. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: we are to retain that market we must pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce beef of the highest quality. The

Speaker: NA
Text: British people made it very plain recently

Speaker: NA
Text: that they require good quality meat and

Speaker: NA
Text: will no longer be satisned, as thcy were in

Speaker: NA
Text: the past, with the second-grade beef whicE

Speaker: NA
Text: we produced because we killed rattle

Speaker: NA
Text: which were too old and which had been

Speaker: NA
Text: subjected to rigorous conditions wbile

Speaker: NA
Text: -being brought to market.

Speaker: NA
Text: The plan to develop our northern areas

Speaker: NA
Text: must concern itself not only with the

Speaker: NA
Text: provision of extra transport facilities, but'

Speaker: NA
Text: also with means to enable tbe meat

Speaker: NA
Text: industry to turn out the highest quality

Speaker: NA
Text: beef that is possible. All the remedies

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been suggested for the present

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties rely on the provision of more

Speaker: NA
Text: railways. During the last year or so, the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals most generally considered have

Speaker: NA
Text: included the extension of one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland railway lines into the west,

Speaker: NA
Text: from Dajarra to a point on the Barkly

Speaker: NA
Text: Tableland. The phrase "the Dajarra

Speaker: NA
Text: railway " has come into common use, par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly in Queensland. Another pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal is that the railway line should be

Speaker: NA
Text: extended from Darwin, through Oentral

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, to link up with Alice Springs.

Speaker: NA
Text: E am not satisned that either of those two

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed rail links, or any other rail

Speaker: NA
Text: would be the best method of develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing our northern areas, but if we

Speaker: NA
Text: are to pin our faith to railway

Speaker: NA
Text: lines, it is necessary for us to consider

Speaker: NA
Text: what the provision of an adequate service

Speaker: NA
Text: for the whole area would involve. I sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: mit that this Government must concern

Speaker: NA
Text: itself not only with a portion of the total

Speaker: NA
Text: area, such as the Barkly Tableland, but

Speaker: NA
Text: with the whole of the northern portion

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Commonwealth. I f that area is to

Speaker: NA
Text: be provided with adequate rail links,

Speaker: NA
Text: railway lines must be provided from the

Speaker: NA
Text: back country to the northern parts,

Speaker: NA
Text: Derby, Wyndham and Darwin, and from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Barkly Tableland to the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: rail termini. Further, the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: term ini must be connected to thc

Speaker: NA
Text: Channel country and north-western New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales. Only by means of such a

Speaker: NA
Text: rail system could we deal adequately witb

Speaker: NA
Text: the present situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now we must consider the cost of sucb

Speaker: NA
Text: an undertaking in relation to the benents

Speaker: NA
Text: that it would provide. The cost would be

Speaker: NA
Text: enormous, and it would take many years to

Speaker: NA
Text: complete the work. It has been estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: that the cost of extending the line

Speaker: NA
Text: from Dajarra to Newcastle Waters would

Speaker: NA
Text: be at least £20,000,000. That is the most

Speaker: NA
Text: conservative estimate I have seen. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: estimates are as high as £40,000,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since the cost of only a small extension

Speaker: NA
Text: would be so great, it can be appreciated

Speaker: NA
Text: that the cost of the network which

Speaker: NA
Text: I consider essential would be hundreds

Speaker: NA
Text: of millions of pounds. I

Speaker: NA
Text: cede tbat the provision of such

Speaker: NA
Text: railways would improve conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: and enable graziers to shift their store

Speaker: NA
Text: cattle from drought areas. The railways

Speaker: NA
Text: would enable cattle to be brought

Speaker: NA
Text: down to the Channel country, possibly

Speaker: NA
Text: even to the coastal areas of Queensland,

Speaker: NA
Text: Jfr. Davidson.

Speaker: NA
Text: for fattening, and weaners and young,

Speaker: NA
Text: stock could be moved, which is not possible

Speaker: NA
Text: at the present time. But the provision

Speaker: NA
Text: of those railways would not result in the

Speaker: NA
Text: production of good quality young beef.

Speaker: NA
Text: The graziers still would be obliged to

Speaker: NA
Text: place the stock on rail and to subject

Speaker: NA
Text: them to rough railway travel for a

Speaker: NA
Text: week or more. There would still be an

Speaker: NA
Text: enormous loss from bruising. That loss

Speaker: NA
Text: is estimated to amount to more than

Speaker: NA
Text: £1,000,000 per annum in Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: link, alone. There would still be the loss of

Speaker: NA
Text: weight, the value of which in Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: also is estimated to be more than

Speaker: NA
Text: £1,000,000 per annum. I n my opinion,

Speaker: NA
Text: the expenditure of a large amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: money for the provision of railways

Speaker: NA
Text: would not overcome the difficulties, and

Speaker: NA
Text: we would not attain the final objective

Speaker: NA
Text: of good quality young beef.

Speaker: NA
Text: In recent years, the movement of beef

Speaker: NA
Text: by air transport bas been developed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although that system has not yet proved

Speaker: NA
Text: to be completely successful, it is worthy

Speaker: NA
Text: of trial by the Government. For some

Speaker: NA
Text: years a small company, assisted by go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment subsidy, has been transporting

Speaker: NA
Text: beef by air from Glenroy to Wyndham

Speaker: NA
Text: on the north-western coast of Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. The operations of that com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany have proved that a large-scale in-

Speaker: NA
Text: troduction of this method of transport

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout Australia would be accom-

Speaker: NA
Text: panied by an element of success. Many

Speaker: NA
Text: people have denounced tbe scheme. Such

Speaker: NA
Text: a scheme, to be successful, must be con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducted in association with relatively small

Speaker: NA
Text: inland abattoirs each of wbich would serve

Speaker: NA
Text: an area within a radius of 50 miles. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: would be necessary for tbose abattoirs

Speaker: NA
Text: to be serviced by freighter aircraft which

Speaker: NA
Text: would take the chilled beef direct to the

Speaker: NA
Text: railhead or seaport. The grazier, after

Speaker: NA
Text: walking his cattle for only 50 miles,

Speaker: NA
Text: could bring them in as prime quality

Speaker: NA
Text: two-year-olds without any loss of weight.

Speaker: NA
Text: The scheme has also demonstrated that

Speaker: NA
Text: the grazier need not keep a large

Speaker: NA
Text: con- herd of scrubbers on his property

Speaker: NA
Text: because he cannot afford to move them.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n other words, the grazier is enabled to

Speaker: NA
Text: double his carrying capacity.

Speaker: NA
Text: The airlift scheme has proved that it

Speaker: NA
Text: is worthy of wider experimentation by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government. I hope that His Excel-

Speaker: NA
Text: lency's statement means that further con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration will be given to tbe problem

Speaker: NA
Text: and that the Government will test tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme, not by seeking a report, but by

Speaker: NA
Text: experimentation, with the result tbat

Speaker: NA
Text: within a short space of time it will be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to ascertain whether it is worth-

Speaker: NA
Text: while saying to the industry, " We are

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to subsidize air beef by so much

Speaker: NA
Text: per lb. and leave it to private enterprise to

Speaker: NA
Text: supply the abattoirs and the freighter

Speaker: NA
Text: aircraft with which to inaugurate the

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme". I f the scheme proved to be

Speaker: NA
Text: successful, within a period of five years

Speaker: NA
Text: we would see a marked difference in the

Speaker: NA
Text: development of the northern areas of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. I f the Government were to

Speaker: NA
Text: apply itself only to an extension of the

Speaker: NA
Text: raihvay line beyond Dajarra, the line

Speaker: NA
Text: would not be completed within at least

Speaker: NA
Text: five years.

Speaker: NA
Text: I refer now to a somewhat similar

Speaker: NA
Text: problem in the Territory of Papua and

Speaker: NA
Text: New Guinea. I call it a Somewhat

Speaker: NA
Text: similar problem, because it is associated

Speaker: NA
Text: with the development of that Territory,

Speaker: NA
Text: but of course i t differs in certain respects

Speaker: NA
Text: from the one to which I have just re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred. Papua is an Australian posses-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion, but the Territory of New Guinea

Speaker: NA
Text: is held by Australia under a trusteeship.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are difficult problems associated

Speaker: NA
Text: witb the civilizing of the natives,

Speaker: NA
Text: and we have to be guided, not only

Speaker: NA
Text: by our own humanitarian principles, but

Speaker: NA
Text: also by certain general principles which

Speaker: NA
Text: are laid down in the United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: Charter under which we hold the trustee-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship. We must ensure that we l i f t the

Speaker: NA
Text: natives from a somewhat primitive state

Speaker: NA
Text: to a state in which they are capable of

Speaker: NA
Text: governing themselves. We must also

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that their inalienable rights to

Speaker: NA
Text: the land on which they live are preserved.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those are tasks of great magnitude, and

Speaker: NA
Text: tasks in relation to which a great deal of

Speaker: NA
Text: experience, tolerance and determination

Speaker: NA
Text: must be exercised i f they are to be per-

Speaker: NA
Text: formed satisfactorily. Associated with

Speaker: NA
Text: that problem is the problem of the eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic development of the Territory of

Speaker: NA
Text: Papua and New Guinea. Australia is

Speaker: NA
Text: tackling the problem, but it is important

Speaker: NA
Text: that we should proceed more rapidly

Speaker: NA
Text: than we have been proceeding because of

Speaker: NA
Text: the importance of the Territory to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, not only from the economic point

Speaker: NA
Text: of view, but also from the defence point

Speaker: NA
Text: of view.

Speaker: NA
Text: The majority of people realize that a

Speaker: NA
Text: rapid development of Papua and New

Speaker: NA
Text: Guinea is vital to Australia. The problem

Speaker: NA
Text: of the economic development of Papua

Speaker: NA
Text: and New Guinea is one that calls for the

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing into production of vast areas

Speaker: NA
Text: that are virgin jungle country. Any one

Speaker: NA
Text: who has been there knows that a lot of the

Speaker: NA
Text: country is what i3 commonly described as

Speaker: NA
Text: tiger country and that it cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: developed easily. Although it cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: developed easily, it is country that would

Speaker: NA
Text: handsomely repay the expenditure of

Speaker: NA
Text: capital and effort. The extensive use

Speaker: NA
Text: of machinery is necessary for its rapid

Speaker: NA
Text: development. J. do not know whether

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Territories ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Hasluck) agrees with me, but I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is not available in Papua or

Speaker: NA
Text: New Guinea a pool of cheap native labour

Speaker: NA
Text: upon which we can draw in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: service the projects upon wbich we wish

Speaker: NA
Text: to embark.

Speaker: Mr HASLUCK
Text: Tha t is quite correct.

Speaker: Mr DAVIDSON
Text: Therefore , any

Speaker: NA
Text: plan under which, the Government seeks

Speaker: NA
Text: to develop the Teriitory, or under which

Speaker: NA
Text: it seeks to assist private enterprise,

Speaker: NA
Text: depends, not only upon the acquisition

Speaker: NA
Text: of the land from the natives on just and

Speaker: NA
Text: proper terms, but also upon the expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture of a large amount of capital for the

Speaker: NA
Text: provision of mechanical equipment. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government could play an important part

Speaker: NA
Text: by providing capital on suitable terms.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is also a need for large-scale experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentation. The Department of Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: merce and Agriculture has made a valu-

Speaker: NA
Text: able contribution in the solving of agricul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tural problems, in the provision of better

Speaker: NA
Text: varieties of rubber trees, in the develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of cocoa production and the produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of other agricultural items such as

Speaker: NA
Text: kenaf fibre. That assistance requires the

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure of money. For that reason,

Speaker: NA
Text: I was pleased to hear the reference by His

Speaker: NA
Text: Excellency to the fact that the rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: investigation and classification of land

Speaker: NA
Text: and water resources would be increased.

Speaker: NA
Text: I sincerely hope that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: realizes that the fulfilment of the under-

Speaker: NA
Text: taking will require the expenditure of

Speaker: NA
Text: more money. Increased expenditure on

Speaker: NA
Text: an expansion of the work at present being

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken by the Papua and New

Speaker: NA
Text: Guinea Administration and the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Government not only will

Speaker: NA
Text: accelerate .development of the Territory,

Speaker: NA
Text: but. also will return good, dividends to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. The flow of exports from any

Speaker: NA
Text: area, particularly from a new country

Speaker: NA
Text: such as the Territory of Papua and New

Speaker: NA
Text: Guinea, is a reliable indication of the

Speaker: NA
Text: manner in which development is proceed-

Speaker: NA
Text: ine. The latest reports available reveal

Speaker: NA
Text: that exports from Papua in 1948-49

Speaker: NA
Text: amounted to £934,112. I n 1952-53,

Speaker: NA
Text: Panuan exports totalled £2,322,905. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: four years the value of exports from this

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory increased by £1,388,793. This

Speaker: NA
Text: i.s an indication of the rate at which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory is developing. I n the same

Speaker: NA
Text: period exports from New Guinea in-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr .SPEAKER -Order ! The honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's time has expired.

Speaker: Mr JOSHUA
Text: Ballarat) [4.47] -Th e

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks of the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Dawson ( Mr Davidson) were of great

Speaker: NA
Text: interest to the House, because they

Speaker: NA
Text: followed practical lines. Thoughts ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pressed in this manner are encouraging

Speaker: NA
Text: to the entire community. I am sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member will agree that i f

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is to receive the f u l l benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: such developments as the transport of

Speaker: NA
Text: prime beef by air, we must make certain

Speaker: NA
Text: organizational changes, and it is to that

Speaker: NA
Text: aspect of our affairs that I wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: address myself. When I was elected to

Speaker: NA
Text: this House in 1951, tbe Australian Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth was celebrating its jubilee

Speaker: NA
Text: after 50 years of federation, and i t was

Speaker: NA
Text: not necessary for any one then to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that the old idea,of Empire had gorse,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that Australia was well established as

Speaker: NA
Text: an independent nation.. The entire coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try resounded with speeches expressing

Speaker: NA
Text: those sentiments. Since 1951 our national

Speaker: NA
Text: objectives, have become obscure. Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia has faltered in its progress to-

Speaker: NA
Text: wards its goal, which should bave been

Speaker: NA
Text: stated in the strongest possible terms in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Governor-General's Speech'.

Speaker: NA
Text: omission to do that caused me much dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment. Australia's economic and.

Speaker: NA
Text: military independence must be sought

Speaker: NA
Text: with the utmost vigour, but theGovern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment seemsto have neglected the need

Speaker: NA
Text: for vigorous action.. Certainly, economic,

Speaker: NA
Text: and military independence are being,

Speaker: NA
Text: sought, but not with vigour. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: want any one to think that my reference

Speaker: NA
Text: tO' military independence is. intended to

Speaker: NA
Text: convey that in my view Australia can, be

Speaker: NA
Text: so well armed and powerful that it can

Speaker: NA
Text: defeat any adversary. That is not soi I

Speaker: NA
Text: mean tbat Australia must become comv

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely independent, of other countries

Speaker: NA
Text: for its supplies i n the event of its having

Speaker: NA
Text: to take part in any conflict. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that we can enjoy the full benefitsof OUT.

Speaker: NA
Text: natural resources, and of much of the

Speaker: NA
Text: progress of which the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Dawson spoke, by looking more to our

Speaker: NA
Text: economic independence than to basing

Speaker: NA
Text: our economy on overseas markets.

Speaker: Mr HAMILTON
Text: Wha t does the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member mean by tbat remark?'

Speaker: Mr JOSHUA
Text: Th e honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: beiwill understand as I proceed. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor-General's Speech stated Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's goal in loose, vague and easy-

Speaker: NA
Text: going terms. I n fact, one cannot learn

Speaker: NA
Text: from it what our goal is. Tbe Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General said, at page 1 of the printed 1

Speaker: NA
Text: copy of the Speech-

Speaker: NA
Text: My advisers regard their responsibilities

Speaker: NA
Text: during the life of this Parliament to be the-

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthening of Australia's security, the

Speaker: NA
Text: maintenance of a healthy economy, the-

Speaker: NA
Text: of developmentof. our national, resources, and'

Speaker: NA
Text: the social welfare of the Australian people-

Speaker: NA
Text: That sounds pleasant, but it might be said*

Speaker: NA
Text: about any new nation. There is nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: new in that part of the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General's Speech. The Governor-General

Speaker: NA
Text: said also, at page 2 of the printed copy

Speaker: NA
Text: of his Speech-

Speaker: NA
Text: My Government is undertaking a re-organiza-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the defence programme to achieve the--

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum security

Speaker: NA
Text: He does not say " independent security "--

Speaker: NA
Text: that the eountry can provide for a long period,

Speaker: NA
Text: having regard t'o the needs not only of defence-

Speaker: NA
Text: but also of economic stability, a steady develops

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of population and resources, and high-

Speaker: NA
Text: levels of production and employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: That sort of thing lulled some honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members off to sleep. I noticed, while tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: The Governor-General was delivering his

Speaker: NA
Text: Speech, that, in spite of hi? efforts to

Speaker: NA
Text: make it sound interesting, a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members nodded their heads

Speaker: NA
Text: and went to sleep. Their slumber seemed

Speaker: NA
Text: to become even moredeepwhen, at page

Speaker: NA
Text: 3 of the printed copy of the Speech, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor-General observed-

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is a fundamental' part of the' policy of

Speaker: NA
Text: my Government tliat the development of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia should, proceed at the highest practicable'

Speaker: NA
Text: rate. This requires an adequate supply of

Speaker: NA
Text: (labour ana materials-; sound policies for

Speaker: NA
Text: .encouraging .private investment and an inflow

Speaker: NA
Text: of capital; . , .

Speaker: NA
Text: Tliese declarations sound encouraging, but

Speaker: NA
Text: tbey really mean little. A clear and

Speaker: NA
Text: definite statement of Australia's goal as

Speaker: NA
Text: a .nation and of measures to achieve and

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain .economic and military indepen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence is clearly necessary, and should

Speaker: NA
Text: have been .given on this occasion. One

Speaker: NA
Text: might have taken a little comfort had

Speaker: NA
Text: the Speech promised action to achieve

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's national goal. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment -will be judged in the future on its

Speaker: NA
Text: .present actions, but the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: O.eneral'is Speech contained no promise

Speaker: NA
Text: of action. All that is proposed is merely

Speaker: NA
Text: the sidestepping of the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibilities, as the Governor-General

Speaker: NA
Text: -clearly revealed, when he said at page

Speaker: NA
Text: '4 of the printed copy of his Speeeh-

Speaker: NA
Text: The liiiumfautciringindustries of Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is lioped, will continue their development,

Speaker: NA
Text: -so 'vital i o the national .strength. My Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment w i l l 'continue to accord adequate .protec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to efficient and economic Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: industries. I n doing so, i t will rely for

Speaker: NA
Text: on the 'Tariff Board.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Speech, of course, is made on the

Speaker: NA
Text: advice of the Prime Minister. I do not
