Text: raising the remuneration of the lowest

Speaker: NA
Text: wage-earner. I do not necessarily quarrel

Speaker: NA
Text: with that. I do not agree with it, but I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not criticize them for having taken that

Speaker: NA
Text: attitude. But it is of no use for them to

Speaker: NA
Text: try to convince us now that for years they

Speaker: NA
Text: have been eating their hearts out and

Speaker: NA
Text: battling for increased margins for skilled

Speaker: NA
Text: workers. On the contrary, a little

Speaker: NA
Text: research will reveal dozens of statements

Speaker: NA
Text: opposing any increased reward for skilled

Speaker: NA
Text: work. I do not wish to pursue this argu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment indefinitely. I merely utter this

Speaker: NA
Text: word of warning: I t is of no use to regard

Speaker: NA
Text: every worker in the community as a

Speaker: NA
Text: skilled worker.

Speaker: Mr CURTIN
Text: Wh y not?

Speaker: Mr GULLETT
Text: Becaus e he is not

Speaker: NA
Text: skilled. Many trades which already

Speaker: NA
Text: receive a considerable loading for skill

Speaker: NA
Text: are skilled only to a slight degree. By

Speaker: NA
Text: that I mean that honorable members of

Speaker: NA
Text: this chamber could learn them in a few

Speaker: NA
Text: months, and I do not believe that that

Speaker: NA
Text: represents a very high degree of skill.

Speaker: NA
Text: like the honorable member for Wills ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bryson), have many industrial concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate, and I daresay I know as

Speaker: NA
Text: much about them as he knows about the

Speaker: NA
Text: undertakings in his constituency. Prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: ably I see mine more often than he sees

Speaker: NA
Text: his. I have found that, in most factories,

Speaker: NA
Text: both the management and the employees

Speaker: NA
Text: agree that the most skilled workers are

Speaker: NA
Text: under-paid to-day. They receive any-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing up to £5 above the basic wage. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: few instances is the margin greater than

Speaker: NA
Text: that, as honorable members opposite arc

Speaker: NA
Text: well aware. Take, for example, thc

Speaker: NA
Text: toolmaker. He is a highly skilled man

Speaker: NA
Text: who is required to serve a full apprenticehere to-day.

Speaker: NA
Text: ship and also to expend considerable sums

Speaker: NA
Text: of money on tools, books and other

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements. A skilled toolmaker in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country should be rewarded as he is in

Speaker: NA
Text: the United Kingdom and the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America. I n those countries he

Speaker: NA
Text: gets a margin which brings his remunera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion up to that of the well salaried man.

Speaker: Mr CURTIN
Text: ^-How much does he get?

Speaker: Mr GULLETT
Text: Th e honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber will appreciate that it is not easy to-

Speaker: NA
Text: pluck a figure out of the air in dollars

Speaker: NA
Text: that will mean anything much; but the

Speaker: NA
Text: toolmaker in tbe United States of America

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly gets up to three or four times the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic wage.

Speaker: Mr CURTIN
Text: I n this country his-

Speaker: NA
Text: margin over the basic wage is £2 10s. a

Speaker: NA
Text: week.

Speaker: Mr GULLETT
Text: Tha t is not correct

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to the award about which the-

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member is supposed to know

Speaker: NA
Text: something. I f the honorable member-

Speaker: NA
Text: will look at that award he will find out

Speaker: NA
Text: that he is wrong. I agree witb the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member in principle that the present

Speaker: NA
Text: margin is insufficient; but it is of no use-

Speaker: NA
Text: to use the skilled worker such as the tool-

Speaker: NA
Text: maker or the shearer as a peg by which to

Speaker: NA
Text: pull up the wages of everybody else. If"

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member really feels so

Speaker: NA
Text: deeply for the riveters, boilermakers and'

Speaker: NA
Text: others in whom he is interested, by all

Speaker: NA
Text: means let him champion their cause, but

Speaker: NA
Text: they will not be helped i f they are to be-

Speaker: NA
Text: forced to carry unskilled persons with

Speaker: NA
Text: them in their claims for increased'

Speaker: NA
Text: margins. A margin means a difference,

Speaker: NA
Text: and a claim for an increased margin does-

Speaker: NA
Text: I , not mean a claim for a general increase-

Speaker: NA
Text: of wage levels. That is my warning on.

Speaker: NA
Text: this subject. I f the claim for increased

Speaker: NA
Text: margins for skilled workers is to be used'

Speaker: NA
Text: to attempt to increase the whole scale of

Speaker: NA
Text: wages generally, regardless of skill, the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole object will be defeated, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: skilled worker will not benefit. With

Speaker: NA
Text: that sole proviso, I am prepared to go-

Speaker: NA
Text: just as far as any honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite, ancl so is everybody else on this

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the chamber, because we all realize-

Speaker: NA
Text: that as our economy becomes more com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plex, we become more dependent upon

Speaker: NA
Text: the skilled worker. I say without fear of"

Speaker: NA
Text: contradiction that i f it were not for

Speaker: NA
Text: skilled workers we should not be sitting

Speaker: Mr CURTIN
Text: No , the skilled workers-

Speaker: NA
Text: would be sitting here.

Speaker: Mr GULLETT
Text: I t would be a change-

Speaker: NA
Text: to have some skilled workers. We are-

Speaker: NA
Text: sick of your type.

Speaker: NA
Text: I propose to speak now of some things-

Speaker: NA
Text: that were in the Governor-General's-

Speaker: NA
Text: Speech itself, and then of some opinions-

Speaker: NA
Text: whicli His Excellency has expressed-

Speaker: NA
Text: as it is desirable he should-on

Speaker: NA
Text: public occasions. The whole Speech was

Speaker: NA
Text: based, of course, on tbe belief of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Menzies") and his

Speaker: NA
Text: advisers, which they have made clear in

Speaker: NA
Text: tbis House, tbat tbe danger to this coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try is increasing and is now very great,

Speaker: NA
Text: and tbat, therefore, we must all be pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to make sacrifices in the interests

Speaker: NA
Text: of a greater s^mrity effort. To my way

Speaker: NA
Text: of thinking, a greater defence effort does

Speaker: NA
Text: not mean only the pouring of money into

Speaker: NA
Text: armed forces. It means also a greater

Speaker: NA
Text: effort to establish our home security.

Speaker: NA
Text: His Excellency said that there would be

Speaker: NA
Text: an all-round increase of our defence

Speaker: NA
Text: effort and, in particular, that there would

Speaker: NA
Text: be a greatly increased effort in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Air Eorce and the Navy. We may

Speaker: NA
Text: take it, I think, without reading any-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing into the Speech which was not

Speaker: NA
Text: there, that the Army is to be somewhat

Speaker: NA
Text: played down, while the other services are

Speaker: NA
Text: to be advanced. No doubt that decision

Speaker: NA
Text: was taken on expert advice, and it ill-

Speaker: NA
Text: becomes people who cannot possibly know

Speaker: NA
Text: much about the subject as the advisers

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Prime Minister know, to question

Speaker: NA
Text: that advice. Of course, any advice

Speaker: NA
Text: which stresses the need for increased

Speaker: NA
Text: technical services rather than the train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of men for war would be welcomed

Speaker: NA
Text: by any government because we are faced

Speaker: NA
Text: with a very acute man-power shortage.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, I believe that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: is more ready to accept that advice than

Speaker: NA
Text: advice to the contrary. Insofar as one

Speaker: NA
Text: has been able to gather Labour's defence

Speaker: NA
Text: policy from speeches of honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers opposite in this debate, it appears

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are not in favour of training

Speaker: NA
Text: large numbers of men. Without seeking

Speaker: NA
Text: to refute the views of the experts, I

Speaker: NA
Text: merely wish to utter a word of warning.

Speaker: NA
Text: Campaigns and wars in which we have

Speaker: NA
Text: been involved since the end of World

Speaker: NA
Text: War II. have not shown that a greater

Speaker: NA
Text: accent is needed on the support weapons

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Air Force and the Navy. On the

Speaker: NA
Text: contrary, we were unable to force a deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion iri' Korea because our purely military

Speaker: NA
Text: strength was not overwhelming com oared

Speaker: NA
Text: with that of the North Koreans.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was not weakness in the air, because

Speaker: NA
Text: we had overwhelming superiority in that

Speaker: NA
Text: department. It was not weakness on the

Speaker: NA
Text: seas, because there was no comparison

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Gullett.

Speaker: NA
Text: between the strength of our naval forces

Speaker: NA
Text: other and tbat of the enemy. Exactly the

Speaker: NA
Text: same course of events may be observed in

Speaker: NA
Text: Indo-China. Tbe defeat of the French

Speaker: NA
Text: was due to lack of suflicient highly trained

Speaker: NA
Text: and skilled troops, and to insufficient

Speaker: NA
Text: modern armaments. The French had

Speaker: NA
Text: overwhelming superiority in the other

Speaker: NA
Text: departments.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am bound to say, too, that any pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal for a slackening of our armed

Speaker: NA
Text: effort will find no favour with me, because

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that the national service training

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme is of great benefit to this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: One does not need to be a 4 f t . 2 in. jack-

Speaker: NA
Text: booted Prussian to hold these views, and

Speaker: NA
Text: all honorable members have probably had

Speaker: NA
Text: similar experiences of these matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many young men wont into national

Speaker: NA
Text: service training camps without a very

Speaker: NA
Text: clear idea of their duty to the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some, perhaps, came from towns, and had

Speaker: NA
Text: little contact with country boys, and

Speaker: NA
Text: vice versa. Others were born with silver

Speaker: NA
Text: spoons in their mouths, and had

Speaker: NA
Text: no contact with boys who sold newspapers

Speaker: NA
Text: on street corners, and so on. The

Speaker: NA
Text: difference in the young men drawn from

Speaker: NA
Text: various classes, after three months'

Speaker: NA
Text: national service training, is marvellous.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a real asset to Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: young men leave the camps, after they

Speaker: NA
Text: have performed a service for their coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try, and they feel that they have a greater

Speaker: NA
Text: stake in it. I introduce this matter only

Speaker: NA
Text: to illustrate the point that tbe national

Speaker: NA
Text: service training scheme, quite apart from

Speaker: NA
Text: the purely military virtues that it pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sesses of maintaining our army at maxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mum strength, has the great virtue also

Speaker: NA
Text: of instilling the spirit of citizenship.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since the Parliament re-assembled,

Speaker: NA
Text: many honorable members on both sides of

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe chamber have made statements on

Speaker: NA
Text: passive defence. I do not know

Speaker: NA
Text: whether defence is possible against the

Speaker: NA
Text: atomic bomb, but this I do know, that

Speaker: NA
Text: London, Coventry, Berlin and other cities

Speaker: NA
Text: which were heavily bombed in World War

Speaker: NA
Text: II . , stood up to the ordeal because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: inherent discipline of their people. That

Speaker: NA
Text: discipline was born as the result of

Speaker: NA
Text: military service, or association with mili-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary service, or a kindred organization.

Speaker: NA
Text: I cannot emphasize too strongly my belief

Speaker: NA
Text: in the extent to which our national

Speaker: NA
Text: character is developed by sacrifices made

Speaker: NA
Text: by individuals in one or other of tbe forces,

Speaker: NA
Text: and not necessarily tbe armed forces; but,

Speaker: NA
Text: unforunately, in these time, tbe armed

Speaker: NA
Text: forces constitute almost the only outlet of

Speaker: NA
Text: activitiy of that kind in which our young

Speaker: NA
Text: people may serve. I shall not proceed

Speaker: NA
Text: with a discussion of those matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Governor-General has referred

Speaker: NA
Text: from time to time quite publicly to our

Speaker: NA
Text: military effort, and not precisely in the

Speaker: NA
Text: same terms as those used in his Speech to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliament on the 4th August, last. I

Speaker: NA
Text: noticed, on one occasion, that His Excel-

Speaker: NA
Text: lency said that, so far, we had been just

Speaker: NA
Text: playing with the national service scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think he used that phrase. Whatever

Speaker: NA
Text: our personal opinions may be on this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter, it must be borne in mind that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have in Sir William Slim a Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General who was one of the first captains

Speaker: NA
Text: of his age. On military matters, be is as

Speaker: NA
Text: good an adviser as any government in

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe world may hope to get at tbe present

Speaker: NA
Text: time. We are indeed fortunate to have

Speaker: NA
Text: him

Speaker: Mr CLYDE CAMERON
Text: I rise to order.

Speaker: NA
Text: .[ think that you, Mr Speaker, have ruled

Speaker: NA
Text: in the past that an honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: may not praise or condemn the Queen's

Speaker: NA
Text: representative. I agree with everything

Speaker: NA
Text: that the honorable member for Henty has

Speaker: NA
Text: said about His Excellency the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General but I point out that i f license is

Speaker: NA
Text: given honorable members to praise His

Speaker: NA
Text: Excellency, it may also be given to them

Speaker: NA
Text: to blame him. Therefore, the introduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of His Excellency's name into the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate is a dangerous practice.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! The Stand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Orders provide that the name of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor-General shall not be introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: into a debate.

Speaker: Mr GULLETT
Text: I am sorry, Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker. I shall make no further refer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence to that matter. I thought that tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: manner of my reference to His Excellency

Speaker: NA
Text: would excuse the lapse.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister has spoken of the

Speaker: NA
Text: gravity of the international situation and

Speaker: NA
Text: of the necessity for an increased defence

Speaker: NA
Text: effort. Where is that increased effort to

Speaker: NA
Text: come from? What is the defence effort

Speaker: NA
Text: based on now? As we all know, the

Speaker: NA
Text: defence of this country consists, in a sense,

Speaker: NA
Text: of'two parts. We have the hard core of

Speaker: NA
Text: permanent sailors, soldiers and airmen,

Speaker: NA
Text: without whom, in peace or war, no organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: zation of effort is possible. I n addition,

Speaker: NA
Text: Ave have seen, since the advent of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, the establishment in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia of three permanent battalions and

Speaker: NA
Text: at least part of an up-to-date armoured

Speaker: NA
Text: regiment. Those are great assets, and

Speaker: NA
Text: they provide the hard core around which

Speaker: NA
Text: everything, in a sense, must be built. But

Speaker: NA
Text: alongside them we have the voluntary

Speaker: NA
Text: forces which are known as the Citizen

Speaker: NA
Text: Military Forces. The members of those

Speaker: NA
Text: forces take charge of the national service

Speaker: NA
Text: trainees after three months' basic

Speaker: NA
Text: training.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not believe that this country is

Speaker: NA
Text: capable of supporting a large permanent

Speaker: NA
Text: army, and even i f it were, I do not con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider tbat we could enlist a large per-

Speaker: NA
Text: manent army. Our army advisers tell

Speaker: NA
Text: us to-day that the number of our per-

Speaker: NA
Text: manent troops, so far from increasing, is

Speaker: NA
Text: constantly on the decline. The answer to

Speaker: NA
Text: that problem is deep-seated. We may be

Speaker: NA
Text: described as a martial people, but we are

Speaker: NA
Text: not in any sense a military people. Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians do not like service in the armed

Speaker: NA
Text: forces merely for the sake of being in

Speaker: NA
Text: them. I f there is a war, a camp or a

Speaker: NA
Text: trip of some kind, Australians will be

Speaker: NA
Text: in it, but they have no desire, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: main, to serve in the forces in peace-time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, I consider that it is futile to

Speaker: NA
Text: speak of the establishment of a large per-

Speaker: NA
Text: manent armed force, however attractive

Speaker: NA
Text: the idea may be.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no more comfortable theory

Speaker: NA
Text: than that the defence of the country can

Speaker: NA
Text: be left to a permanent force of 20,000,

Speaker: NA
Text: 30,000 or even 50,000 men, and the rest

Speaker: NA
Text: of us citizens have no responsibilities

Speaker: NA
Text: other than to pay our taxes. Such a

Speaker: NA
Text: theory will not work in these times unless

Speaker: NA
Text: we are prepared to conscript our citizens

Speaker: NA
Text: for service in the permanent army. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not think that any one w i l l advocate

Speaker: NA
Text: such a course. The only way, then, in

Speaker: NA
Text: which we can rapidly increase our effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive effort is through the voluntary

Speaker: NA
Text: system, that is to say, the Citizen Mili-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary Forces. I n that department, a great

Speaker: NA
Text: deal can be done. From time to time

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House have risen in their places and

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended to the Government the

Speaker: NA
Text: adoption of certain steps in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: -the Citizen Military Forces. I firmly

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that if the claim that much more

Speaker: NA
Text: must be done to increase our defence

Speaker: NA
Text: -effort is sincere, it is time that notice

Speaker: NA
Text: was taken of some of the matters that

Speaker: NA
Text: bave been raised.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the moment, the voluntary forces

Speaker: NA
Text: are dependent almost entirely on a rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively . small number of men, most of

Speaker: NA
Text: whom served in the last war. I say

Speaker: NA
Text: most of them served in the last war,

Speaker: NA
Text: because some young men, who have

Speaker: NA
Text: graduated from the national service

Speaker: NA
Text: training scheme, are becoming available.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are the ones on whom our hopes for

Speaker: NA
Text: the future must be built. The burden

Speaker: NA
Text: now falls on the officers and non-com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioned officers, and it is a great

Speaker: NA
Text: burden. I am sure that the House and

Speaker: NA
Text: the country have not a proper concep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the great sacrifices made by those

Speaker: NA
Text: men, and the splendid work performed

Speaker: NA
Text: by them in a voluntary capacity. For

Speaker: NA
Text: their services, they should be suitably

Speaker: NA
Text: rewarded. Their militia pay, as I havf-.

Speaker: NA
Text: said repeatedly in the past, should not

Speaker: NA
Text: be subject to tax. One of these men may

Speaker: NA
Text: be in receipt of a wage or salary of £15

Speaker: NA
Text: -or £20 a week. He may receive, for his

Speaker: NA
Text: part-time army service, £50 or £'70 per

Speaker: NA
Text: -annuni. The additional money places

Speaker: NA
Text: him in a higher int-mno bracket, and

Speaker: NA
Text: when he pays tax, he is not much better

Speaker: NA
Text: off than he would have been i f he had not

Speaker: NA
Text: received payment for his services in the

Speaker: NA
Text: forces. I t must also be remembered that

Speaker: NA
Text: such a service involves a man in certain

Speaker: NA
Text: -expenditure on uniforms, fares, clothing

Speaker: NA
Text: and the like. There is always a credir.

Speaker: NA
Text: and debit side, particularly for officer?

Speaker: NA
Text: and non-commissioned officers, and many

Speaker: NA
Text: -of these men are badly off as the result

Speaker: NA
Text: -of the service that they render to the

Speaker: NA
Text: country. I f anything can be done to

Speaker: NA
Text: assist this group of men, i t should be done.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is not good enough to say that con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration will be given to the matter, tbat

Speaker: NA
Text: we shall look into it thoroughly or tbat

Speaker: NA
Text: we shall submit it to the Treasury. The

Speaker: NA
Text: time has come for action.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the main, the British defence scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: has been built on much the same basis as

Speaker: NA
Text: -ours, but whereas we have lost almost all

Speaker: NA
Text: -of our volunteers since the introduction

Speaker: NA
Text: -of compulsory training, the British have

Speaker: NA
Text: -retained theirs. The reason is that they

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Qullett.

Speaker: NA
Text: have put so much more into their scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have put into ours. They give

Speaker: NA
Text: their young men extra facilities and privi-

Speaker: NA
Text: leges. I hope we shall do the same.

Speaker: Mr BIRD
Text: Batman) [5.36] -Th e

Speaker: NA
Text: Speech of the Governor-General, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: main, is an insipid document, containing

Speaker: NA
Text: a collection of vague platitudes and

Speaker: NA
Text: generalities. I t is remarkable, not so

Speaker: NA
Text: much, for its contents as for its omissions.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 propose to deal with a few of the state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in it. Among other things, His

Speaker: NA
Text: Excellency said-

Speaker: NA
Text: My Governniunt will continue, with other

Speaker: NA
Text: nations, its practical contribution to the

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare of the South and South-East Asian

Speaker: NA
Text: area through the Colombo Plan. Such

Speaker: NA
Text: measures of help encourage sympathetic under-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing and goodwill.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am a great supporter of the Colombo

Speaker: NA
Text: plan because I believe tbat i f it achieves

Speaker: NA
Text: what its sponsors intended it will have a

Speaker: NA
Text: far-reaching effect on our relations with

Speaker: NA
Text: Asian countries. The Colombo plan was

Speaker: NA
Text: born early in 1950, because conditions in

Speaker: NA
Text: Asia demanded a new approach to the

Speaker: NA
Text: problems there. The majority of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 600,000,000 people in South-East Asia

Speaker: NA
Text: were undernourished, tbeir housing facili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties were notoriously inadequate, illiteracy

Speaker: NA
Text: was the lot of 80 per cent, of them, and

Speaker: NA
Text: their expectation of life was less than 30

Speaker: NA
Text: years. Therefore, the countries of the

Speaker: NA
Text: British Commonwealth in the area got

Speaker: NA
Text: together and decided that they ought to

Speaker: NA
Text: make an endeavour to raise the standards

Speaker: NA
Text: of living of those people, not only as a

Speaker: NA
Text: humanitarian action, but also, I suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: seriously, as a means to counter the spread

Speaker: NA
Text: of communism there. I t can be said

Speaker: NA
Text: safely tbat, at any rate theoretically,

Speaker: NA
Text: the plan is a co-operative enterprise by

Speaker: NA
Text: which the more highly developed countries

Speaker: NA
Text: of the area will help the less developed

Speaker: NA
Text: countries by giving tbem financial aid and

Speaker: NA
Text: technical assistance. I f one accepts the

Speaker: NA
Text: statements in the Speech of the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General, it seems tbat the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is satisfied with the progress

Speaker: NA
Text: of thc plan. But I am by no means satis-

Speaker: NA
Text: fied with it. There are a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects that give no cause for complacency

Speaker: NA
Text: or self-satisfaction.

Speaker: NA
Text: I base my opinion on the second annual

Speaker: NA
Text: report of tbe Consultative Committee of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Colombo plan, issued in New Delhi

Speaker: NA
Text: in October of last year. Any one who

Speaker: NA
Text: reads the report, at length, as I have done,

Speaker: NA
Text: will find that i t gives scant satisfaction

Speaker: NA
Text: to ardent supporters of the plan. The

Speaker: NA
Text: contents of the report lead one to believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Colombo plan, which came i n

Speaker: NA
Text: with a bang, w i l l go out with a whimper.

Speaker: NA
Text: Three and a half years have elapsed since

Speaker: NA
Text: -the foreign ministers of the countries

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible f o r the plan inaugurated what

Speaker: NA
Text: I thought would Ibe a new era of interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional relations, an era that could well

Speaker: NA
Text: alter the destiny of mankind. The min-

Speaker: NA
Text: isters met i n :an atmosphere of apparent

Speaker: NA
Text: urgency and the scheme was initiated and

Speaker: NA
Text: put under way quickly. Since then, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Consultative Committee has met i n

Speaker: NA
Text: London, Colombo, Karachi and New

Speaker: NA
Text: Delhi. I understand i t will meet in

Speaker: NA
Text: Ottawa in October of this year. When

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian representative goes' to

Speaker: NA
Text: Ottawa, I hope he w i l l not be imbued

Speaker: NA
Text: with the smug satisfaction with which

Speaker: NA
Text: apparently the Government was imbued

Speaker: NA
Text: when i t prepared the Governor-General's

Speaker: NA
Text: Speech. The second annual report of the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee contains a number of disquiet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing statements about tbe progress of the

Speaker: NA
Text: plan. I t reveals that the difficulties faced

Speaker: NA
Text: by many countries have become formid-

Speaker: NA
Text: able. I n view of the nature of the report,

Speaker: NA
Text: we have no cause to be jubilant about the

Speaker: NA
Text: progress achieved so f a r . Tbe report

Speaker: NA
Text: states-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Colomho Plan programmes are reaching

Speaker: NA
Text: a crucial stage. The countries of the area

Speaker: NA
Text: have shown their determination to carry them

Speaker: NA
Text: through, and the decline in export earnings,

Speaker: NA
Text: wliile it has added greatly to the difficulty

Speaker: NA
Text: of the task has made it more than ever neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary to press ahead with the developmental

Speaker: NA
Text: programmes . . . The present flow 'of

Speaker: NA
Text: external financial aid must he continued and,

Speaker: NA
Text: if possible, increased. The difficulties are

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed formidable.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am concerned about the reaction that

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties and failures w i l l have on the

Speaker: NA
Text: minds of the people of Asia, whose friend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship we are tryin g to w i n through the

Speaker: NA
Text: operation of the plan. Dealing with the

Speaker: NA
Text: national incomes of the less developed

Speaker: NA
Text: countries of the area, the report states-

Speaker: NA
Text: The fall in export earnings led to a fall

Speaker: NA
Text: in national incomes. This caused rather

Speaker: NA
Text: widespread economic distress and the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trast with the previous high expectations

Speaker: NA
Text: produced a general feeling of frustration and

Speaker: NA
Text: bewilderment.

Speaker: NA
Text: To me, those are ominous words. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: appears that the sponsors of the plan are

Speaker: NA
Text: preparing the ground f o r an announce-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that we have failed to earry out the

Speaker: NA
Text: original concept. I n 1950, i t was

Speaker: NA
Text: envisaged that assistance would be given

Speaker: NA
Text: to the less developed countries of South

Speaker: NA
Text: and South-East Asia i n the fields of agri-

Speaker: NA
Text: culture, power and communications. We

Speaker: NA
Text: were told that more land would be placed

Speaker: NA
Text: under cultivation and irrigation, more

Speaker: NA
Text: food would be produced and power

Speaker: NA
Text: generating capacity would be increased.

Speaker: NA
Text: The sponsors of the plan realized, as they

Speaker: NA
Text: stated i n the preamble to i t , that because

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe population of the area was increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: at the rate of -8,000,000 a year, the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gramme envisaged would do little more

Speaker: NA
Text: than maintain existing standards of

Speaker: NA
Text: living, which were lamentably low. Tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: report of the Consultative Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: reveals that, although development has

Speaker: NA
Text: proceeded on those lines, i t has not

Speaker: NA
Text: reached anywhere near the stage contem-

Speaker: NA
Text: plated when the plan was formulated.

Speaker: NA
Text: According to the report, statistics show

Speaker: NA
Text: that, althougli there has been some

Speaker: NA
Text: development i n certain fields, development

Speaker: NA
Text: generally has not reached the stage i t

Speaker: NA
Text: -should have reached after three years of

Speaker: NA
Text: activity. I say incidentally that the

Speaker: NA
Text: -Government has given the Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: but little opportunity to discuss the plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: Is there any significance i n the improve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments that have been made? What are

Speaker: NA
Text: -the prospects for the immediate future?

Speaker: NA
Text: Are the living standards of the Asian

Speaker: NA
Text: .peoples being raised enough to compen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sate f o r increases of population ? I f not,

Speaker: NA
Text: -the plan is not doing what was originally

Speaker: NA
Text: intended. The .report makes no attempt

Speaker: NA
Text: to answer those questions. I n the main,

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee bas been content to give

Speaker: NA
Text: an account of material achievements. But

Speaker: NA
Text: the report barely touches the vital

Speaker: NA
Text: questions whether those achievements

Speaker: NA
Text: have contributed significantly to an

Speaker: NA
Text: increase of l i v i n g standards or have made

Speaker: NA
Text: further progress possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n order to assess the real progress tbat

Speaker: NA
Text: has been achieved and the prospects f or

Speaker: NA
Text: tlie future, i t is appropriate to examine

Speaker: NA
Text: the salient features of the plan. We were

Speaker: NA
Text: told that, i n order to provide f o r economic

Speaker: NA
Text: growth and the maintenance of present

Speaker: NA
Text: standards of livin g i n a rapidly increas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing population, i t would be necessary to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase output, and that, i n order to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase output, i t would be necessary to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase investment. But the nations of

Speaker: NA
Text: Asia, because of their poverty-stricken

Speaker: NA
Text: state, were unable to attract capital from

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas until productivity had been

Speaker: NA
Text: increased. I n other words, their economy

Speaker: NA
Text: needed to be primed to enable them to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase production and then attract

Speaker: NA
Text: capital from other countries. The aid

Speaker: NA
Text: contributed under the Colombo plan was

Speaker: NA
Text: intended to act as a detonator to set this

Speaker: NA
Text: process in train. Unfortunately, the

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of the plan has not been achieved

Speaker: NA
Text: because productivity has not been in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased to any appreciable degree. There

Speaker: NA
Text: has been very little investment of foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: capital in Asia since the plan came into

Speaker: NA
Text: operation, and it seems to me that, unless

Speaker: NA
Text: the contributing countries are prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase the scale of their nnanciai aid,

Speaker: NA
Text: the scheme will die on its feet.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, which has acknowledged its

Speaker: NA
Text: obligation to assist in the development

Speaker: NA
Text: these backward countries, has more reason

Speaker: NA
Text: to fear the failure of the scheme than has

Speaker: NA
Text: any other contributing nation. Our future

Speaker: NA
Text: is irrevocably linked with our relation-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships with Asian countries, and the col-

Speaker: NA
Text: lapse of the Colombo plan would re-act

Speaker: NA
Text: much more unfavorably upon us than

Speaker: NA
Text: upon any other country. "We must in all

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances try to prevent the disillu-

Speaker: NA
Text: sionment of the peoples of Asia as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of the failure of the plan. Tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: prosperity of Asia is of the utmost

Speaker: NA
Text: ance to us. It is obvious to me that the

Speaker: NA
Text: volume of aid provided under the scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: has been altogether inadequate. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: spending money hand over fist in other

Speaker: NA
Text: directions, and we should divert some of

Speaker: NA
Text: that expenditure to the more valuable

Speaker: NA
Text: investment that is represented by our

Speaker: NA
Text: contributions to the Colombo plan. The

Speaker: NA
Text: promotion of goodwill in Asia promotes

Speaker: NA
Text: our own security. If the plan is to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve a significant success, it must proprocess

Speaker: NA
Text: duce quick and lasting results. There-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore, the representatives of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment who attend the meeting at Ottawa

Speaker: NA
Text: in October should take the first oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to bring to the notice of the

Speaker: NA
Text: consultative committee the obvious flaws

Speaker: NA
Text: that have developed already in the struc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture of the plan. These faults, though

Speaker: NA
Text: they were not readily discernible in the

Speaker: NA
Text: initial stages of the scheme, have assumed

Speaker: NA
Text: immense proportions and now threaten to

Speaker: NA
Text: destroy the efficacy of the whole project.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ur. Bird.

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration was also mentioned in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor-General's Speech. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has announced tbat it is content to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue with its present immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. Most honorable members will

Speaker: NA
Text: agree, I am sure, that the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of Immigration has done good work, but

Speaker: NA
Text: the effectiveness of its programme will be

Speaker: NA
Text: endangered i f it cannot organize a

Speaker: NA
Text: smoother assimilation of immigrants than

Speaker: NA
Text: is possible under tbe present system. Much

Speaker: NA
Text: closer working arrangements between the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth and the States must be

Speaker: NA
Text: evolved because, up to the present, there

Speaker: NA
Text: has been constant irritation between State

Speaker: NA
Text: and Commonwealth departments in rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to various aspects of immigration.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n my opinion, immigration involves

Speaker: NA
Text: much more than the procurement of immi-

Speaker: NA
Text: grants in othei' countries, tlieir transport

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australia, and their accommodation

Speaker: NA
Text: of for limited periods in hostels. The arrival

Speaker: NA
Text: of large numbers of new citizens requires

Speaker: NA
Text: a rapid extension of social amenities and

Speaker: NA
Text: essential services. We need more schools,

Speaker: NA
Text: hospitals, houses, water, electricity, trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: port and other public services. The obli-

Speaker: NA
Text: gation of supplying tbose services falls at

Speaker: NA
Text: present on State governments. This divi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of responsibility is one of the major

Speaker: NA
Text: weaknesses of the immigration scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: Und cniably, the major defect of the plan

Speaker: NA
Text: is the lack of effective co-operation be-

Speaker: NA
Text: importtween the Commonwealth, which orga-

Speaker: NA
Text: nizes the inflow of immigrants, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: States, which provide the services needed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the increased population. There

Speaker: NA
Text: appears to be a total lack of appreciation

Speaker: NA
Text: by this Government of the financial strain

Speaker: NA
Text: that this obligation places upon the States.

Speaker: NA
Text: They must have substantial additional

Speaker: NA
Text: financial aid i f immigrants are to be

Speaker: NA
Text: assimilated satisfactorily. I n the early

Speaker: NA
Text: stages of the immigration programme, the

Speaker: NA
Text: of assimilation was given far less

Speaker: NA
Text: attention than was that of recruiting

Speaker: NA
Text: immigrants overseas. The prime impulse

Speaker: NA
Text: of both the former Government and this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government was to bring as many immi-

Speaker: NA
Text: grants as possible to Australia and make

Speaker: NA
Text: light of the difficulties that would arise

Speaker: NA
Text: from the rapid population increase.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tbe State governments are eager to

Speaker: NA
Text: establish new arrivals satisfactorily, but

Speaker: NA
Text: they are emphatic that their task cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: be carried out successfully unless this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government acknowledges their need for

Speaker: NA
Text: increased nnanciai aid. They have been

Speaker: NA
Text: called upon to shoulder great responsibili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties, and these, unfortunately, have

Speaker: NA
Text: assumed formidable proportions. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sorry to say that this Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted an airy attitude towards the

Speaker: NA
Text: States. I t seems to imagine that they

Speaker: NA
Text: will be able to muddle through and solve

Speaker: NA
Text: their problems without help.

Speaker: NA
Text: optimism is ill-founded. They cannot.be

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to continue to assume such great

Speaker: NA
Text: liabilities unless provision is made for

Speaker: NA
Text: adequate financial compensation. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Minister for Immigration ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Holt) met State Ministers at a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference on immigration early this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, the discussion at that conference

Speaker: NA
Text: produced a lot of airy platitudes without

Speaker: NA
Text: giving rise to any practical decisions. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: is not enough for the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: merely to provide hostel accommodation

Speaker: NA
Text: and find opportunities for the employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of new Australians. Its responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility goes much further than that. Tlie

Speaker: NA
Text: plain truth is that the prolonged influx

Speaker: NA
Text: of immigrants has vastly increased the

Speaker: NA
Text: demand for public services, the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: providing which should be reckoned as n

Speaker: NA
Text: part of thc cost of a successful immigra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion scheme. Until the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledges and accepts its responsibili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties in this direction, our immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: programme will not he completely

Speaker: NA
Text: successful.

Speaker: NA
Text: For reasons of national security, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: essential for Australia to treble its

Speaker: NA
Text: lation within a reasonable space of time.

Speaker: NA
Text: But, in order to achieve our purpose, we

Speaker: NA
Text: must adjust the machinery of immigra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to enable it to cope with the situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. That machinery can easily break

Speaker: NA
Text: down i f the Government fails to realize

Speaker: NA
Text: that its obligations do not cease as soon

Speaker: NA
Text: as immigrants land on Australian soil.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n fact, at that stage, the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth's responsibility is not even one-

Speaker: NA
Text: quarter discharged. Unfortunately, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has adopted the attitude tbat

Speaker: NA
Text: its worries end when the immigrants

Speaker: NA
Text: arrive and that the task of arranging for

Speaker: NA
Text: their assimilation should fall upon the

Speaker: NA
Text: States. However, tbe ^tate governments,

Speaker: NA
Text: because of their limited financial re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sources are unable to do the job

Speaker: NA
Text: adequately.

Speaker: NA
Text: I come now to a consideration of thc

Speaker: NA
Text: process of naturalization. I t is only

Speaker: NA
Text: natural for immigrants to this country to

Speaker: NA
Text: look forward to attaining the status of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian citizenship, and the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment should exert every influence to

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage them to apply for naturaliza-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion as soon as they become eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: to do so. On the l l t h August,

Speaker: NA
Text: Its I asked the Minister who is. acting for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Immigration ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Beale) whether the naturalization

Speaker: NA
Text: figures in relation to non-British immi-

Speaker: NA
Text: grants indicated a reluctance by thosr

Speaker: NA
Text: people to become Australian citizens.

Speaker: NA
Text: From the Minister's reply, it was evident

Speaker: NA
Text: tbat tens of thousands of immigrants

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled to seek the privilege of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian nationality have not done so.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is a deplorable state of affairs, with

Speaker: NA
Text: which, according to the Minister, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is not satisfied. I consider

Speaker: NA
Text: that we do not fulfil the purpose of

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing people to this coimtry until

Speaker: NA
Text: tbey are naturalized. This matter de-

Speaker: NA
Text: mands urgent consideration.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why are not applications for

Speaker: NA
Text: naturalization being received from immi-

Speaker: NA
Text: grants in greater numbers? We should

Speaker: NA
Text: consider whether the requirements of the

Speaker: NA
Text: law in relation to naturalization are too

Speaker: NA
Text: stringent. Is too high a fee charged ?

Speaker: NA
Text: .Does the nature of the naturalization

Speaker: NA
Text: ceremony act as a deterrent? I n recent

Speaker: NA
Text: years major changes have heen made

Speaker: NA
Text: in order to enhance the dignity

Speaker: NA
Text: of the naturalization ceremony

Speaker: NA
Text: popu- and remove unnecessary deterrents to

Speaker: NA
Text: naturalization. To-day, although the

Speaker: NA
Text: naturalization ceremony is brighter and

Speaker: NA
Text: more dignified than the former pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cedure, the result has not been all that

Speaker: NA
Text: could be desired. I^hoped that the deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of tbe Minister for Immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Holt) some time ago to hold future

Speaker: NA
Text: naturalization ceremonies at town halls,

Speaker: NA
Text: in a congenial atmosphere, would en-

Speaker: NA
Text: courage large numbers of eligible immi-

Speaker: NA
Text: grants to apply for naturalization. Un-

Speaker: NA
Text: fortunately, that has not resulted.

Speaker: NA
Text: According to the Minister's reply to my

Speaker: NA
Text: question, only 1,100 applications wer-3

Speaker: NA
Text: received from non-British immigrants for

Speaker: NA
Text: naturalization in the first six months of

Speaker: NA
Text: this year. There were 1,770 applications

Speaker: NA
Text: last month. Those figures are relatively

Speaker: NA
Text: small, compared with the tens of

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of immigrants who are entitled

Speaker: NA
Text: to seek the status of Australian citizen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship. A fee of £5 is charged for

Speaker: NA
Text: naturalization papers. I consider thai

Speaker: NA
Text: this deters many immigrants from seek-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing naturalization. No fee was charged

Speaker: NA
Text: for 30 years after federation. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: two points of view about the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some people contend that it is well worth

Speaker: NA
Text: £5 to an immigrant to become an Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian citizenOthers believe that there

Speaker: NA
Text: can be no correlation of citizenship to

Speaker: NA
Text: money. An immigrant should not be

Speaker: NA
Text: debarred from naturalization only be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause he is unable to pay this fee.

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigrants who intend to apply for

Speaker: NA
Text: naturalization are required to advertise

Speaker: NA
Text: that fact in two newspapers circulating

Speaker: NA
Text: in the districts in which they live. The

Speaker: NA
Text: object of this legal requirement is to

Speaker: NA
Text: afford to persons who consider thf.

Speaker: NA
Text: advertiser should not be naturalized, an

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to lodge an objection with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of Immigration. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, during the last 36 years fewer than

Speaker: NA
Text: half a dozen such protests hav<j beeu

Speaker: NA
Text: made to the department. Therefore it

Speaker: NA
Text: is obvious that this requirement serves

Speaker: NA
Text: no worthwhile purpose. I point out that,

Speaker: NA
Text: frequently, such an advertisement in a

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper results in the singling out of

Speaker: NA
Text: an alien when he is about to become an

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian citizen. The advertisement

Speaker: NA
Text: pinpoints the fact that he has not already

Speaker: NA
Text: been naturalized. An intending appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant for naturalization is required to

Speaker: NA
Text: notify the department of his intention

Speaker: NA
Text: four years before lodging an applica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Why is such lengthy notice re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired? Our procedure is very complex.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, I point out that it is the

Speaker: NA
Text: bounden duty of the Government to use

Speaker: NA
Text: every endeavour to encourage non-

Speaker: NA
Text: British immigrants to become

Speaker: NA
Text: naturalized. The naturalization pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cedure should be simplified to obviate

Speaker: NA
Text: unnecessary expense to immigrants.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr DEAN)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

Speaker: NA
Text: THE PARLIAMENT.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: It has been reported

Speaker: NA
Text: to me that there is somebody in the

Speaker: NA
Text: gallery with a camera. I wish it to be

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly understood that tbe taking of

Speaker: NA
Text: ilr. Ilird.

Speaker: NA
Text: photographs in this chamber to-night has

Speaker: NA
Text: been prohibited, and that i f anybody

Speaker: NA
Text: takes a photograph he can be dealt with.

Speaker: NA
Text: ESTIMATES 1954-55.

Speaker: NA
Text: Messages from the Governor-General

Speaker: NA
Text: reported transmitting Estimates of

Speaker: NA
Text: Revenue and Expenditure and Estimates

Speaker: NA
Text: of Expenditure for Additions, New

Speaker: NA
Text: Works and Otber Services involving.

Speaker: NA
Text: Capital Expenditure for the year ending

Speaker: NA
Text: the 30th June, 1955, and recommending

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriations accordingly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered to be printed, and referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Committee of Supply forthwith.

Speaker: NA
Text: BUDGET 1954-55.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Committee of Supply:

Speaker: Sir ARTHUR FADDEN
Text: MCPherson-

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer) [8.2] - I desire to place

Speaker: NA
Text: before the House to-night estimates of

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue and expenditure for the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: year 1954-55 and to explain the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals which accompany these esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mates. I desire also to speak briefly on

Speaker: NA
Text: the broad considerations of national policy

Speaker: NA
Text: wbich have guided the Government in

Speaker: NA
Text: framing its budget for this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: THE STATE OF THE ECONOMY.

Speaker: NA
Text: During tbe financial year just closed

Speaker: NA
Text: we had in Australia stability of general

Speaker: NA
Text: economic conditions, combined in remark-

Speaker: NA
Text: able degree with real and substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: material progress. On the one hand, re-

Speaker: NA
Text: tail and wholesale prices were generally

Speaker: NA
Text: steady throughout the year, and so too

Speaker: NA
Text: were wage rates and the other main ele-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments which determine costs. On the

Speaker: NA
Text: other hand, civilian employment increased

Speaker: NA
Text: by no less than 90,000 persons. National

Speaker: NA
Text: income rose by 5 per cent, and, since the

Speaker: NA
Text: price level did not rise, this was a real

Speaker: NA
Text: gain in terms of goods and services. Total

Speaker: NA
Text: wages and salaries paid increased by

Speaker: NA
Text: nearly 7 per cent. Total farm income, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is true, fell by 8 per cent.; but this was a

Speaker: NA
Text: fall from a relatively high level of income

Speaker: NA
Text: in the previous year. There was a rise

Speaker: NA
Text: of nearly 6 per cent, in business and pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: fessional income. Personal consumption

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure was 10 per cent, greater than

Speaker: NA
Text: Over a wide range of industries levels

Speaker: NA
Text: of production ran high. Output of iron

Speaker: NA
Text: and steel, coal, copper, and zinc

Speaker: NA
Text: approached or passed previous record

Speaker: NA
Text: figures and the same is. true of many

Speaker: NA
Text: building materials. There was a. notable

Speaker: NA
Text: increase . in the manufacture of such:

Speaker: NA
Text: diverse articles, as domestic, refrigerators,

Speaker: NA
Text: rayon fabrics, hosiery and motor bodies.

Speaker: NA
Text: Generation of electricity rose above its

Speaker: NA
Text: previous highest point.

Speaker: NA
Text: The volume of retail trade increased

Speaker: NA
Text: considerably and that increase was

Speaker: NA
Text: shared by most branches of business. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: particular, sales of motor cars and house-

Speaker: NA
Text: hold appliances showed an almost spec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tacular growth. Although there was a

Speaker: NA
Text: large increase in supplies, obtained from

Speaker: NA
Text: both local production and imports, tbere

Speaker: NA
Text: d'oes not seem to have been any excessive

Speaker: NA
Text: building-up of stocks.

Speaker: NA
Text: The value of imports for the year was

Speaker: NA
Text: greater than the value of imports in the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous year. Exports for 1953-54

Speaker: NA
Text: amounted to £816,000,000 and although

Speaker: NA
Text: this was £30,000,000 less than exports in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1952-53 is was still a relatively high

Speaker: NA
Text: figure. I t has in fact been exceeded in

Speaker: NA
Text: only two other years.

Speaker: NA
Text: During. 1953-54 the Government made

Speaker: NA
Text: further relaxations of import controls

Speaker: NA
Text: and imports are now running at a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: paratively high level. Until the wool-

Speaker: NA
Text: selling season opens it will not be possible

Speaker: NA
Text: to gauge with any confidence wbat export

Speaker: NA
Text: prospects for the year are likely to be. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: is reasonable to expect some net capital

Speaker: NA
Text: inflow during the year but it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: possible, at. this, stage to estimate the

Speaker: NA
Text: importance of this factor.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the peak of the last export season

Speaker: NA
Text: our international reserves reached

Speaker: NA
Text: £620,000,000. After that there was a

Speaker: NA
Text: moderate' decline and at 30th June last,

Speaker: NA
Text: the reserves stood at £571,000,000, which

Speaker: NA
Text: represented a net addition of £10,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: during the year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Altogether 1953-54 was a period of

Speaker: NA
Text: stable; genuine and widely-spread pros-

Speaker: NA
Text: perity. Perhaps never before in our

Speaker: NA
Text: history have we had a year to equal it.

Speaker: NA
Text: As weturn to prospects' for the coming

Speaker: NA
Text: year' it is natural to ask whether we can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not do as well again, whether we cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: again enjoy balanced and stable economic

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions and yet make at least as great

Speaker: NA
Text: an advance in national development.

Speaker: NA
Text: Cannot these two great objectives of policy

Speaker: NA
Text: again be combined?

Speaker: NA
Text: Conditions necessarily differ from year

Speaker: NA
Text: to year; and last year conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: happened to be, on the whole, favorable

Speaker: NA
Text: to us. Despite the decline in the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States, it remained' a fairly prosperous

Speaker: NA
Text: year foi" the world at large and our

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas trading position continued rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively strong. Internally, we had largely

Speaker: NA
Text: recovered from tbe setback of 1952-53

Speaker: NA
Text: even before the year began, and although

Speaker: NA
Text: there was then a small amount of unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment and some idle plant, those

Speaker: NA
Text: resources were soon absorbed into produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and the whole economy ran along

Speaker: NA
Text: smoothly at or very near full employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I venture to say that the key to our

Speaker: NA
Text: success in 1953-54 lies in just that fact.

Speaker: NA
Text: We were able to bring all our physical

Speaker: NA
Text: resources into employment and yet, for

Speaker: NA
Text: the greater part of the year at any rate,

Speaker: NA
Text: we did not over-strain them. Whilst

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial activity grew and a good rate

Speaker: NA
Text: of development was maintained there

Speaker: NA
Text: was, for the most part, enough labour and

Speaker: NA
Text: materials and enough power and other

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities to meet requirements. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the chief lesson of 1953-54. I t is indeed

Speaker: NA
Text: the chief lesson of the whole post-war

Speaker: NA
Text: period. I f we keep a balance between

Speaker: NA
Text: available resources and the demand for

Speaker: NA
Text: tbose resources we will generally have not

Speaker: NA
Text: only stability of prices and costs but

Speaker: NA
Text: rising output, improving efficiency and

Speaker: NA
Text: sound progress in development. Allow

Speaker: NA
Text: demand for resources to outrun supply

Speaker: NA
Text: and we will almost certainly have disloca-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, waste and a cutting-back of real

Speaker: NA
Text: output and the rate of development. We

Speaker: NA
Text: had a grim experience of those things in

Speaker: NA
Text: the period up to 1952 and I should not

Speaker: NA
Text: need to recall them here.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should not need to be taught that

Speaker: NA
Text: lesson again, learnt as i t was in years of

Speaker: NA
Text: disruption and futility ; and, as things

Speaker: NA
Text: are, i t is, I believe, a lesson that should be

Speaker: NA
Text: very aetive in our minds. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: tasted the fruits of stable progress and,

Speaker: NA
Text: rightly, for our own sakes. we want it. to

Speaker: NA
Text: go on.. We have, nationally, a tremen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dous task to people and develop this con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinent; but we can only hope to perform,

Speaker: NA
Text: that task if we go about i t in an orderly

Speaker: NA
Text: and: effective way.. We have ahead of us,,

Speaker: NA
Text: as the Prime Minister ( Mr Menzies) has

Speaker: NA
Text: related to the House, tlie prospect of

Speaker: NA
Text: major political and strategic commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments abroad, commitments whicli may

Speaker: NA
Text: call for much greater defence efforts and

Speaker: NA
Text: preparations. This last consideration is,

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps, the strongest and most insistent

Speaker: NA
Text: reason of all why we must seek to combine

Speaker: NA
Text: the maximum employment of our resources

Speaker: NA
Text: with a balanced and effective distribution

Speaker: NA
Text: of those resources.

Speaker: NA
Text: Good though recent times have been,

Speaker: NA
Text: there can be no mistaking the signs that

Speaker: NA
Text: stresses are again threatening to develop

Speaker: NA
Text: our economy. During recent months short-

Speaker: NA
Text: ages of labour have increased, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: in the basic industries, such as iron and

Speaker: NA
Text: steel and building, and in the basic ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices, such as railways. Some supplies

Speaker: NA
Text: have also become scarce, amongst them

Speaker: NA
Text: steel and certain building materials.

Speaker: NA
Text: Meanwhile, numerous industries and

Speaker: NA
Text: public undertakings, not actually short of

Speaker: NA
Text: labour and materials for current pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: poses, have been strenuously trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: get more of both in order to expand their

Speaker: NA
Text: activities. Again, demand for consump-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion goods is still tending to increase; as

Speaker: NA
Text: it does so, it provides a stimulus for still

Speaker: NA
Text: further industrial expansion and still

Speaker: NA
Text: further demands for resources. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: a degree of unhealthy financial specula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion going on, though so far it is limited

Speaker: NA
Text: mainly to certain sections of the market.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not want to exaggerate the portents

Speaker: NA
Text: as seen at this time. The current short-

Speaker: NA
Text: ages of labour and materials are not to

Speaker: NA
Text: be compared with the bottlenecks which

Speaker: NA
Text: had such a crippling effect on our economy

Speaker: NA
Text: in the period before 1952. There is no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer any coal shortage. Power supplies

Speaker: NA
Text: appear adequate for the time being and

Speaker: NA
Text: more capacity is rapidly being built.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has been a fairly general improve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment during the past three years in the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic facilities available to us and this

Speaker: NA
Text: should stand us in good stead in the

Speaker: NA
Text: future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nor would I exclude altogether tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: possibility of changes, in some directions

Speaker: NA
Text: during the year which may run counter to

Speaker: NA
Text: the present general trend towards expan-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of demand. Eor example, whilst

Speaker: NA
Text: export prospects on the whole may be

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonably good, it is possible that total

Speaker: NA
Text: export earnings this year will be appre-

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir Arthur Fadden.

Speaker: NA
Text: ciably less than last year. I f this proves

Speaker: NA
Text: to be so it could have some offsetting

Speaker: NA
Text: effect on internal demand and business

Speaker: NA
Text: activity.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nevertheless, the most significant fact

Speaker: NA
Text: at the present time is that pressure upon

Speaker: NA
Text: resources has again appeared in our

Speaker: NA
Text: economy and on present indications seems

Speaker: NA
Text: likely to grow. We will obtain some addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional labour as the year goes on, partly

Speaker: NA
Text: from local sources and partly from immi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gration, and there should be some increase

Speaker: NA
Text: in the supply of goods from local output

Speaker: NA
Text: and from imports. I f , however, the

Speaker: NA
Text: in present general quest for labour continues,

Speaker: NA
Text: and i f demand for goods keeps rising,

Speaker: NA
Text: these additional resources may well be

Speaker: NA
Text: swallowed up, leaving demands still un-

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfied. Labour will tend to shift away

Speaker: NA
Text: from the basic industries and key mate-

Speaker: NA
Text: rials will become scarcer. The defence

Speaker: NA
Text: effort and developmental projects will be

Speaker: NA
Text: retarded and industrial productivity will

Speaker: NA
Text: fall. All tbis could happen even though,

Speaker: NA
Text: on the face of things, the economy might

Speaker: NA
Text: appear active and business thriving. Such

Speaker: NA
Text: a situation would clearly not be avoided

Speaker: NA
Text: by indiscriminate mass immigration;

Speaker: NA
Text: recent experience has taught us that the

Speaker: NA
Text: immediate effect of large-scale immigra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is to add at least as much to the

Speaker: NA
Text: demand for labour as i t does to the supply

Speaker: NA
Text: of labour.

Speaker: NA
Text: Were inflationary conditions to return

Speaker: NA
Text: we could expect at a fairly early stage the

Speaker: NA
Text: beginning of a new upward thrust of

Speaker: NA
Text: prices and costs. That, I suggest, is

Speaker: NA
Text: about the last thing any of us wishes to

Speaker: NA
Text: see. During the inflation years our

Speaker: NA
Text: general level of costs was raised inordin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ately high-fa r too high for a country

Speaker: NA
Text: like ours which, on the one hand, depends

Speaker: NA
Text: upon selling so much of its products in

Speaker: NA
Text: markets abroad and which, on the other

Speaker: NA
Text: hand, has been rapidly establishing new

Speaker: NA
Text: industries to compete in our own markets

Speaker: NA
Text: with the products of other countries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Furthermore, the success or failure of

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the greatest developmental pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: jects now being undertaken in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: -th e Snowy Mountains scheme, for

Speaker: NA
Text: example - depend fundamentally upon

Speaker: NA
Text: one question, the question whether costs

Speaker: NA
Text: can be kept at economic levels.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first thing to do about the problem

Speaker: NA
Text: of costs is, obviously, to ensure that costs

Speaker: NA
Text: rise no higher. I f the general forces

Speaker: NA
Text: whicli influence costs can be kept stable,

Speaker: NA
Text: then the particular factors which

Speaker: NA
Text: normally work towards the reduction of

Speaker: NA
Text: costs will have a chance to operate. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: is through these factors that higher

Speaker: NA
Text: national productivity will be achieved-

Speaker: NA
Text: and the obverse of higher productivity is

Speaker: NA
Text: lower cost levels. Those factors, however,

Speaker: NA
Text: thrive and find play only in the conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: of a stable and balanced.economy. "We

Speaker: NA
Text: have had these conditions for the past

Speaker: NA
Text: year or so and, unquestionably for that

Speaker: NA
Text: reason, there are signs that some ground

Speaker: NA
Text: has been won in the attack on costs. Not

Speaker: NA
Text: a few industries have been able to report

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing output from the capital and

Speaker: NA
Text: labour they employ. Such promising

Speaker: NA
Text: tendencies will, however, quickly be over-

Speaker: NA
Text: borne i f a scramble for resources gets

Speaker: NA
Text: under way again, i f business goes out to

Speaker: NA
Text: chase the ephemeral profits of inflation

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than the profits of efficiency and

Speaker: NA
Text: if labour falls again for the delusion of

Speaker: NA
Text: so-called " attraction " wage rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: To say this is to say again-i t cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: be too often repeated-tha t the cost

Speaker: NA
Text: problem is the responsibility of every one.

Speaker: NA
Text: Governments and other public authorities

Speaker: NA
Text: liave an important share in that responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility. I t is for them to lighten taxes

Speaker: NA
Text: charges, to avoid undue competition for

Speaker: NA
Text: resources and to use their powers and

Speaker: NA
Text: conduct their operations in a way that

Speaker: NA
Text: will promote a state of economic balance.

Speaker: NA
Text: But i t is labouring the obvious to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that industry and trade and those who

Speaker: NA
Text: work and share in them also have

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility as great as, i f not greater

Speaker: NA
Text: than, that of governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: FINANCIAL POLICY.

Speaker: NA
Text: Such broadly is the context within

Speaker: NA
Text: which the budget for the current year has

Speaker: NA
Text: been prepared. The Government has had

Speaker: NA
Text: to weigh carefully the various elements

Speaker: NA
Text: in this rather complex situation. I t has

Speaker: NA
Text: had to consider wbere and how far

Speaker: NA
Text: restraint should be exercised and where

Speaker: NA
Text: and bow far encouragement should be

Speaker: NA
Text: given. The problem has been by no means

Speaker: NA
Text: exclusively an economic and financial one.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have had very much in our minds tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: international prospect- a prospect whieh

Speaker: NA
Text: plainly decrees that we should, as far as

Speaker: NA
Text: possible, husband our strength, financially

Speaker: NA
Text: and otherwise, against the burdens and

Speaker: NA
Text: stresses which may well lie just ahead of

Speaker: NA
Text: us.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the expenditure side the right policy

Speaker: NA
Text: must obviously be one of firm control.

Speaker: NA
Text: That some branches of expenditure should

Speaker: NA
Text: increase is, under present circumstances,

Speaker: NA
Text: inevitable. Defence and social services

Speaker: NA
Text: are examples. Where, again, works

Speaker: NA
Text: projects subject to contracts are making

Speaker: NA
Text: headway, additional provision for ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: penditure cannot be avoided. Subject to

Speaker: NA
Text: considerations like these, however, it

Speaker: NA
Text: would be wrong, at a time when com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity spending as a whole is on the rise,

Speaker: NA
Text: to make large additions to public expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture. One of the most important factors

Speaker: NA
Text: making for general stability in the past

Speaker: NA
Text: two years bas been the overall restraint

Speaker: NA
Text: iipon governmental spending. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly no time to abandon that

Speaker: NA
Text: restraint.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the revenue side the Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: in a position to make further tax reduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions as it foreshadowed in the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's policy speech. I t proposes to

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce taxes up to the limit of budget

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity after niaking provision for essen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial expenditure and having regard to the

Speaker: NA
Text: and commitments Australia may soon have to

Speaker: NA
Text: face: and it has devised the tax reduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions in a way that will ensure the maxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mum incentive to effort while making

Speaker: NA
Text: wherever possible a direct reduction in

Speaker: NA
Text: costs. At the same time i t has taken care

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that the budget for the year

Speaker: NA
Text: will balance; for there could be no

Speaker: NA
Text: thought at a time like this of adding to

Speaker: NA
Text: the volume of spending power by the

Speaker: NA
Text: process of deficit-financing.

Speaker: NA
Text: This year the Government has given no

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaking to assist Loan Council bor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rowing programmes from revenue as it

Speaker: NA
Text: had to do on a large scale in the last three

Speaker: NA
Text: years, when public loan raisings fell far

Speaker: NA
Text: short of borrowing requirements. Since,

Speaker: NA
Text: however, the Commonwealth has agreed

Speaker: NA
Text: with the States that the full amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: loan money raised this year, either from

Speaker: NA
Text: local or overseas sources, will be applied

Speaker: NA
Text: towards the Loan Council programmes,

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole of its own expenditures, includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing capital expenditures, will have to be

Speaker: NA
Text: met from its own resources. This is not

Speaker: NA
Text: something we are doing willingly. We

Speaker: NA
Text: would in fact be very glad to finance a

Speaker: NA
Text: large part, i f not the whole, of our

Speaker: NA
Text: capital works from loan moneys. .But

Speaker: NA
Text: since sufficient loan money is not yet

Speaker: NA
Text: available for all the capital requirements

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Commonwealth ancl the States,

Speaker: NA
Text: the only alternative to financing our

Speaker: NA
Text: capital works from sources othei than-

Speaker: NA
Text: loan funds would be to take a part of

Speaker: NA
Text: the money which is now being made avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able for Stato works programmes. I

Speaker: NA
Text: might point out, however, that thanks

Speaker: NA
Text: to the notable revival in tbe loan market

Speaker: NA
Text: in the past year, a much larger propor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of Australian works expenditure is

Speaker: NA
Text: now being financed from loan moneys

Speaker: NA
Text: than was the case two -or three years ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: A survey of Loan Transactions and Pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lic Debt in 1953-54 is given in Statement

Speaker: NA
Text: No. 2 which is a supplement to this

Speaker: NA
Text: speech.

Speaker: NA
Text: EXPENDITURE ESTIMATES. 1.954-55.

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Services.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Prime Minister ha." already

Speaker: NA
Text: announced, the budget appropriation for

Speaker: NA
Text: defence this year will be £200,000,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, there is the Defence Equip-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and Supplies Trust Account of

Speaker: NA
Text: £12,000,000 which was set up during

Speaker: NA
Text: 1953-54 and which will be held available

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Treasury as a reserve from which

Speaker: NA
Text: to meet any additional commitments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thus funds that can be made available

Speaker: NA
Text: for defence purposes this year will be

Speaker: NA
Text: nearly £35,000,000 greater than the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of £177,000,000 which was the

Speaker: NA
Text: total of cash expenditure on defence dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: War and Bepatriation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has decided to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease general rate war pensions under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Repatriation Act by 7s. 6d. per week,

Speaker: NA
Text: thus making the 100 per cent, general rate

Speaker: NA
Text: £4 10s. a week.

Speaker: NA
Text: The rate of war widows' pensions will

Speaker: NA
Text: also be increased by 7s. 6d. per week, so

Speaker: NA
Text: raising it to £4 a week.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new rates will be paid from the

Speaker: NA
Text: first pension pay-day after the necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation has been passed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The cost of these increases is expected

Speaker: NA
Text: to be about £1,900,000 in a full year and

Speaker: NA
Text: Hir Arthur Fadden.

Speaker: NA
Text: National Welfare Fund.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n accordance with the undertakings

Speaker: NA
Text: -it gave in the policy speech the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment proposes to raise the permissible

Speaker: NA
Text: income for age, invalid and widows' pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions from £2 to £3 10s. a week.

Speaker: NA
Text: The property limit will be raised to

Speaker: NA
Text: £1,750 and the property exemption will

Speaker: NA
Text: be raised from £150 to £200. Income

Speaker: NA
Text: from property will in future be dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: regarded i n applying the income test.

Speaker: NA
Text: This provision will assist particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: those pensioners who own houses, but,

Speaker: NA
Text: while unable to obtain possession, arc

Speaker: NA
Text: receiving rent from tenants. Tbe legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation already provides the Director-

Speaker: NA
Text: General of Social Services with discre-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionary power to exclude from the

Speaker: NA
Text: property test the value of houses belong-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to pensioners in this position, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the discretion will be exercised freely in

Speaker: NA
Text: future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Blind persons eligible for pension will

Speaker: NA
Text: in future be paid the full pension of

Speaker: NA
Text: £3 10s. a week free of the means test.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sc:n:i 90,000 pensioners will receive

Speaker: NA
Text: increases in t'heir pensions as a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: the liberalized means test. I n addition,

Speaker: NA
Text: many thousands of pensioners will be

Speaker: NA
Text: brought into the pensions field and

Speaker: NA
Text: receive part pensions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The increases (including those for

Speaker: NA
Text: blind pensioners) will be paid from tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: first pension pay-day after the necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation has been passed.

Speaker: NA
Text: When these measures have been brought

Speaker: NA
Text: into account and provision made for the

Speaker: NA
Text: normal increases in the numbers of social

Speaker: NA
Text: service beneficiaries and the expansion of

Speaker: NA
Text: health, medical and other services, the

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure from the National Welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: Eund is expected to be £16,800,000

Speaker: NA
Text: greater than in 1953-54. Details of the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Welfare Fund are contained in

Speaker: NA
Text: Statement No. 5.

Speaker: NA
Text: Homes for the A.ged.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the policy speech the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: undertook to provide, on a £l-for-£l basis,

Speaker: NA
Text: money towards capital costs incurred by

Speaker: NA
Text: churches and recognized charitable insti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tutions for building homes for the aged,

Speaker: NA
Text: up to a total Commonwealth contribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of £1,500,000 a year. Provision has

Speaker: NA
Text: been made in the budget for this amount

Speaker: NA
Text: and details of a scheme are at present

Speaker: NA
Text: being formulated.

Speaker: NA
Text: Payments to the States.

Speaker: NA
Text: Total payments to the States this yeai'

Speaker: NA
Text: are estimated to be £198,665,000 com-

Speaker: NA
Text: The tax reimbursement grant payable

Speaker: NA
Text: to the .States under the formula laid

Speaker: NA
Text: down in existing legislation is estimated
