Speaker: NA
Text: REVENUE ESTIMATES, 1954-55.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the basis of present rates of taxa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, it is estimated that total revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: This includes revenue from taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: £936,856,000, and other revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: £113,244,000, ancl is approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: £33,000,000 greater than actual revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: Although incomes of both individuals

Speaker: NA
Text: and companies upon which income tax

Speaker: NA
Text: is currently being assessed were larger

Speaker: NA
Text: last year than in the year before, and

Speaker: NA
Text: although wages and salary payments,

Speaker: NA
Text: imports and sales can be expected to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase again this year, it has to be

Speaker: NA
Text: remembered that revenue in 1954-55 will

Speaker: NA
Text: bear a full year's cost of the largo and

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensive tax reductions made in

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1953-54 budget. That full year cost

Speaker: NA
Text: was estimated at £118,000,000 on the

Speaker: NA
Text: basis of conditions at the time. I t would

Speaker: NA
Text: be substantially greater on the basis of

Speaker: NA
Text: current conditions and prospects. The

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue estimates for 1954-55 are set out

Speaker: NA
Text: and explained in detail in Statement No.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3 attached to this speech.

Speaker: NA
Text: If revenue were to stand at

Speaker: NA
Text: £1.050,100,000 and p-nenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: £l,'014j849j000 there would be a budget

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir Arthur Fadden.

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus of £35,251,000. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: proposes to make tax reductions worth

Speaker: NA
Text: £46.600,000 a year to taxpayers, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: is estimated that tbe cost of these tax

Speaker: NA
Text: reductions in 1954-55 will, be £35,000,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: TAXATION PROPOSALS.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having this amount of scope for tax

Speaker: NA
Text: reductions, the Government has con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered very carefully the form such

Speaker: NA
Text: reductions could most appropriately take

Speaker: NA
Text: under present circumstances. I t has

Speaker: NA
Text: decided that, as iu last year's budget,

Speaker: NA
Text: the greatest weight should be given to

Speaker: NA
Text: reductions of income tax on individuals.

Speaker: NA
Text: By so doing, the benefits will be spread

Speaker: NA
Text: most widely and the greatest number of

Speaker: NA
Text: people will receive a further incentive to

Speaker: NA
Text: work and to save.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has, however,

Speaker: NA
Text: explored the possibilities of reducing

Speaker: NA
Text: indirect taxation and it is proposing some

Speaker: NA
Text: very useful reductions in that field. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: of tliese reductions will make an

Speaker: NA
Text: important direct contribution to the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem of reducing costs. Others, again,

Speaker: NA
Text: will be very helpful to the householder

Speaker: NA
Text: and the familv man. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has also examined at great length the

Speaker: NA
Text: vexed question of depreciation allowances,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I shall have something to say on

Speaker: NA
Text: that important subject presently.

Speaker: NA
Text: Meanwhile, I wish to give the main

Speaker: NA
Text: details of our tax proposals.

Speaker: NA
Text: INCOME TAX AND SOCIAL SERVICES

Speaker: NA
Text: CONTRIBUTION.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bates of Tax: Individuals.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is proposed to reduce the rates of

Speaker: NA
Text: individual income tax and social services

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution as from, the 1st July, 1954.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reduction will bu graduated over all

Speaker: NA
Text: income ranges and will represent an

Speaker: NA
Text: overall decrease of 9 per cent, on existing

Speaker: NA
Text: rates. Statement No. 6 illustrates the

Speaker: NA
Text: reductions for taxpayers at selected income

Speaker: NA
Text: levels and with various family respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibilities. The reductions in tax range

Speaker: NA
Text: from approximately 20 per cent, on the

Speaker: NA
Text: lower incomes to about 8 per cent, for

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers with incomes between £8,000

Speaker: NA
Text: and £16,000. On the excess of income

Speaker: NA
Text: over £16,000 the new rates scale will

Speaker: NA
Text: terminate at a maximum rate of 13s. 4d.

Speaker: NA
Text: in the £1 instead of the present 14s.

Speaker: NA
Text: at The rates of instalment deductions will

Speaker: NA
Text: be reduced as from the 1st October, 1954,

Speaker: NA
Text: which, is the earliest date by which it will

Speaker: NA
Text: be possible to prepare and distribute the

Speaker: NA
Text: new instalment schedules. I n the case of

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers who are subject to provisional

Speaker: NA
Text: tax, the reductions will be reflected in

Speaker: NA
Text: decreased amounts of provisional tax for

Speaker: NA
Text: The reductions in the individual rates

Speaker: NA
Text: will cost revenue £31,250,000 in a full

Speaker: NA
Text: year and £23,200,000 in the current year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Successive tax reductions effected by

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government have very substantially

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced the burden of income tax on all

Speaker: NA
Text: classes of taxpayers. I t is significant that

Speaker: NA
Text: tho new rates represent an overall reduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of almost 30 per cent, on the rates

Speaker: NA
Text: in force when the Government came into

Speaker: NA
Text: office. Statement No. 7 compares income

Speaker: NA
Text: tax in Australia, TJnited Kingdom and

Speaker: NA
Text: New Zealand and shows that income

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers in Australia are paying con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderably less than those in the other two

Speaker: NA
Text: countries.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is proposed to allow deductions of

Speaker: NA
Text: gifts of £1 or more to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Elizabethan Theatre Trust, the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Academy of Science and to public funds

Speaker: NA
Text: for tbe acquisition, construction and

Speaker: NA
Text: maintenance of school and college build-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings used by non-profit organizations.

Speaker: NA
Text: These concessions will cost revenue about

Speaker: NA
Text: £200,000 in a full year, but there will be

Speaker: NA
Text: no cost in 1954-55.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mining.

Speaker: NA
Text: Amounts received for the grant, assignincome

Speaker: NA
Text: ment or surrender of mining leases are,

Speaker: NA
Text: at present, assessable income of

Speaker: NA
Text: recipients and deductible in the assessdeceased

Speaker: NA
Text: ments of tbe payers. Assessability of the

Speaker: NA
Text: amounts received has, i t is thought, proved

Speaker: NA
Text: a deterrent in some cases to mining

Speaker: NA
Text: development. I t is proposed, accordingly,

Speaker: NA
Text: to place these transactions outside the

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax field unless the parties to a

Speaker: NA
Text: transaction agree that such payments

Speaker: NA
Text: should continue to be assessable

Speaker: NA
Text: one hand and deductible on tbe other.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the existing legislation, income

Speaker: NA
Text: is exempt from tax i f it is derived by a

Speaker: NA
Text: bona fide prospector from the sale of

Speaker: NA
Text: rights to mine for gold and certain other

Speaker: NA
Text: metals and minerals which are prescribed

Speaker: NA
Text: by regulation. This exemption applies

Speaker: NA
Text: to a company which has itself carried

Speaker: NA
Text: out the major part of the field work

Speaker: NA
Text: prospecting, but it does not extend to

Speaker: NA
Text: dividends paid by the company out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: exempt income. I t is proposed that,

Speaker: NA
Text: where dividends are paid wholly and ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: clusively out of the exempt income, the

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders shall be free from income

Speaker: NA
Text: tax on those dividends.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is further proposed to extend the

Speaker: NA
Text: list of metals and minerals prescribed for

Speaker: NA
Text: the purpose of tbe foregoing exemption.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is estimated that the cost in a full

Speaker: NA
Text: year will be £15,000. There will be no

Speaker: NA
Text: cost to revenue in 1954-55.

Speaker: NA
Text: Purchased Annuities.

Speaker: NA
Text: At present, an annual allowance is

Speaker: NA
Text: made, in the annuitant's assessment, for

Speaker: NA
Text: the purchase price paid by him for an

Speaker: NA
Text: annuity for life, but this allowance ceases

Speaker: NA
Text: when he has attained his expectation of

Speaker: NA
Text: life as actuarially calculated. The loss of

Speaker: NA
Text: this allowance increases the tax payable

Speaker: NA
Text: by the annuitant at a time when he may

Speaker: NA
Text: Oifts. be least able to bear an increased tax

Speaker: NA
Text: burden. I t is proposed to remove this

Speaker: NA
Text: limitation so that the annuitant will be

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled to the allowance throughout his

Speaker: NA
Text: lifetime.

Speaker: NA
Text: The cost in a full year will be about

Speaker: NA
Text: £15,000. I n this year there will be no

Speaker: NA
Text: cost to revenue.

Speaker: NA
Text: United Kingdom War Pensions.

Speaker: NA
Text: At present, United Kingdom pensions

Speaker: NA
Text: payable to disabled servicemen resident in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia are exempt from Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: tax. I t is proposed to extend this

Speaker: NA
Text: exemption, as from the 1st July, 1954, to

Speaker: NA
Text: the the widows and other dependants of

Speaker: NA
Text: United Kindom servicemen.

Speaker: NA
Text: The exemption will then be in conformity

Speaker: NA
Text: with the exemption of pensions paid by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth to widows and other

Speaker: NA
Text: dependants of Australian servicemen.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n a full year there will be a cost to

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue of about £20,000 but no cost in

Speaker: NA
Text: on the this financial year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sales Tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: The rate of tax on furniture and certain

Speaker: NA
Text: household equipment, including crockery,

Speaker: NA
Text: cutlery, floor coverings and household

Speaker: NA
Text: appliances, will be reduced from 12^ per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, to 10 per cent. This reduction,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is expected to cost £4,376,000 in a

Speaker: NA
Text: of full year and £3,400,000 in the current

Speaker: NA
Text: year, should be particularly useful to

Speaker: NA
Text: people setting up homes.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is also proposed to reduce from 16f

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent, to 12-J per eent. the rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: tax on toys, fireworks, amusement equip-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, musical instruments, confectionery

Speaker: NA
Text: and ice-cream. These reductions are ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pected to cost £1,714,000 in a full year and

Speaker: NA
Text: A number of important items will be

Speaker: NA
Text: wholly exempted from sales tax. Amongst

Speaker: NA
Text: these items are several which have a direct

Speaker: NA
Text: bearing on the costs of industry or con-

Speaker: NA
Text: structional work.

Speaker: NA
Text: Eor example, hand tools, are to be

Speaker: NA
Text: exempted at a cost to revenue of £2,530,000

Speaker: NA
Text: in a full year and £1,800,000 in the

Speaker: NA
Text: current year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Certain types of industrial machinery

Speaker: NA
Text: and equipment are also to be exempted,

Speaker: NA
Text: amongst them being machinery for the

Speaker: NA
Text: r pair and maintenance of manufacturing

Speaker: NA
Text: plant, repair plant used in the mining

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, machinery for use by contrac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors engaged in building and the construc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of roads, dams and similar works.

Speaker: NA
Text: The cost of revenue of exempting this

Speaker: NA
Text: group is expected to be £1,210,000 in a

Speaker: NA
Text: full year and £9,00,000 in the current

Speaker: NA
Text: year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Aircraft and aircraft parts will be

Speaker: NA
Text: exempted at a cost to revenue of £869,000

Speaker: NA
Text: in a full year and '£800,000 in the current

Speaker: NA
Text: year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Paper bags, wrapping paper and string

Speaker: NA
Text: will be exempted at a cost of £1,800,000

Speaker: NA
Text: in ,a full year and £1,400,000 in 1954-55.

Speaker: NA
Text: Exemption is also proposed for 'bottles

Speaker: NA
Text: and cases used in the soft drink industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: for clock systems and time recorders for

Speaker: NA
Text: business and industrial use 'and for a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of miscellaneous items which at

Speaker: NA
Text: present constitute anomalies i n the

Speaker: NA
Text: administration of sales tax. The cost to

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue of these exemption's is estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: at £3.23,000 in :a full year and ,£259,000 in

Speaker: NA
Text: the current year.

Speaker: NA
Text: All told the sales tax concessions I have

Speaker: NA
Text: just outlined are expected to have a value

Speaker: NA
Text: to taxpayers of £12,822,000 in a full year

Speaker: NA
Text: and £9,892,000 in 1954-55. Pull details

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: business to-morrow.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir Arthur Fadden.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pay-roll Tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is proposed to raise the annual

Speaker: NA
Text: exemption from £4,160 to £6,240. On

Speaker: NA
Text: sales a weekly basis, this is an increase from

Speaker: NA
Text: £80 per week to £120 per week. The

Speaker: NA
Text: higher exemption will operate in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of wages payable on or after the 1st

Speaker: NA
Text: September, 1954.' Tax will be payable

Speaker: NA
Text: Only on the excess of wages over the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of £120 per week. This amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will exempt a further l'O^OO

Speaker: NA
Text: employers from pay-roll tax and reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: the amount of tax payable by those still

Speaker: NA
Text: subject to this tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is .also proposed to exempt wages

Speaker: NA
Text: paid by non-profit private hospitals, thus

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing tbe pay-roll tax law into line

Speaker: NA
Text: with the income tax and sales tax laws,

Speaker: NA
Text: which already allow concessions to such

Speaker: NA
Text: hospitals. Up to the present, the pay-roll

Speaker: NA
Text: tax exemption in respect of hospitals has

Speaker: NA
Text: been limited to public hospitals.

Speaker: NA
Text: The loss of revenue resulting from

Speaker: NA
Text: these concessions will be £1,810,000 in a

Speaker: NA
Text: full year and £1,508,000 in 1954-55.

Text: on brandy by 30s. per proof gallon. 'The

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: full year and £400,000 in the current

Speaker: NA
Text: financial year.

Text: f u l l yenr 1054-53. DEPRECIATION.

Speaker: NA
Text: f

Speaker: NA
Text: As I liave already said, the Governmeut

Speaker: NA
Text: has considered very closely the question

Speaker: NA
Text: of income tax allowances i n respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: depreciation. The subject has been widely

Speaker: NA
Text: discussed publicly and we have had many

Speaker: NA
Text: representations on i t f r o m various sections

Speaker: NA
Text: 3,400,000 of industry. We have also obtained a

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth of expert advice and we have

Speaker: NA
Text: examined the measures taken i n a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of other countries. I could not hope to

Speaker: NA
Text: discuss the subject i n all its ramifications

Speaker: NA
Text: 225,000 here, but there are a few relevant con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderations which I think should be stated

Speaker: NA
Text: at this point.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is, without doubt, an extra-

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinary range and diversity of opinion

Speaker: NA
Text: on this issue. Much of the diversity seems

Speaker: NA
Text: to spring from the fact that people who

Speaker: NA
Text: put particular proposals forward have

Speaker: NA
Text: 800,000 different objects i n view. Some, for

Speaker: NA
Text: example, are concerned with the problem

Speaker: NA
Text: of wbat has come to be called " capital

Speaker: NA
Text: 250,000 erosion" which arises when, as a result

Speaker: NA
Text: of the increase i n costs during a period

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,800,000 of inflation, the replacement of plant

Speaker: NA
Text: requires a capital expenditure much

Speaker: NA
Text: higher than the original cost of the plant.

Speaker: NA
Text: Others are concerned not so mucli with

Speaker: NA
Text: the problem of financing the replacement

Speaker: NA
Text: of bid plant as w i th the active stimula-

Speaker: NA
Text: 800.000 tion of investment i n new plant in exist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and i n entirely new enterprises.

Speaker: NA
Text: Others, again, direct their minds to the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,400,000 replacement of plant i n the future, this

Speaker: NA
Text: with a view to promoting .a more rapid

Speaker: NA
Text: 259,000 scrapping of plant, whether already in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stalled or to be installed i n tbe future.

Speaker: NA
Text: 9,892,000 Many of the proposals tbat have been

Speaker: NA
Text: put forward contemplate adjustments of

Speaker: NA
Text: the depreciation provisions of the income

Speaker: NA
Text: tax laws which, while leaving taxpayers

Speaker: NA
Text: liable eventually to more or less the same

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,508,000 amount of taxation, would permit them to

Speaker: NA
Text: re-arrange tlieir capital programmes so

Speaker: NA
Text: as to ease their particular problems of

Speaker: NA
Text: financing plant -installation or replace-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Other proposals, however, go

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond this and suggest what, i n fact, i f

Speaker: NA
Text: not i n form , would be a subsidy ( i n the

Speaker: NA
Text: shape of tax remissions) to purchasers

Speaker: NA
Text: of new plant, this at the expense of

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of this type are proposals based on the

Speaker: NA
Text: system of investment allo-wances recently

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted in tbe TJnited Kingdom. The Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment has given particular attention

Speaker: NA
Text: to these proposals which have a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of advocatesin Australia, and has found

Speaker: NA
Text: that they have features which are not

Speaker: NA
Text: acceptable under our conditions. I n thc

Speaker: NA
Text: -first place, such allowances would apply

Speaker: NA
Text: only to new plant and would therefore be

Speaker: NA
Text: of no benefit to firms which have already

Speaker: NA
Text: set up their establishments and are net

Speaker: NA
Text: likely to extend them. Secondly, while

Speaker: NA
Text: an attempt might be made to confine such

Speaker: NA
Text: a. subsidy to certain types of capital

Speaker: NA
Text: assets or certain sectors of industry, in

Speaker: NA
Text: practice this would prove so difficult as

Speaker: NA
Text: to be well-nigh impossible. The result

Speaker: NA
Text: in that case would be to give an indis-

Speaker: NA
Text: criminate stimulus to all types of new-

Speaker: NA
Text: capital investment and tbe cost to revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: would become extremely high. Eor these

Speaker: NA
Text: and other reasons the Government cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: accept proposals of this type.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another proposal which has had many

Speaker: NA
Text: -thoug h a decreasing number of-ad -

Speaker: NA
Text: vocates is the special initial depreciation

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance, of which we had experience in

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier post-war years. The particular

Speaker: NA
Text: feature of this method is that it produces

Speaker: NA
Text: ti large tax saving to the taxpayer in the

Speaker: NA
Text: first year after new plant is acquired, and

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore it too gives a strong but indis-

Speaker: NA
Text: criminate stimulus to new investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t was largely for this reason that the

Speaker: NA
Text: system was abandoned under the infla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionary conditions of 1951. With pres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sure upon resources again developing in

Speaker: NA
Text: our economy, this would hardly be an

Speaker: NA
Text: opportune time to restore that system

Speaker: NA
Text: even i f it were acceptable on other

Speaker: NA
Text: grounds. In. any case it has proved i n

Speaker: NA
Text: practice, both here and elsewhere, to

Speaker: NA
Text: have other defects as a. normal feature of

Speaker: NA
Text: an. income tax system.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have cited investment allowances and

Speaker: NA
Text: special initial depreciation allowances as

Speaker: NA
Text: particular proposals which have been

Speaker: NA
Text: prominent in recent discussions. I cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: here review the many other schemes which

Speaker: NA
Text: liave been brought under notice, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: do wish to make a comment on the exist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing depreciation provisions of the taxa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion law.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir Arthur Fadden.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the opinion of some authorities these

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions contain certain defects and

Speaker: NA
Text: anomalies, although it is conceded that

Speaker: NA
Text: generally they provide a basis upon Avhich

Speaker: NA
Text: a reasonably satisfactory system of depre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciation allowances can be built. These

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities at least believe that, insofar

Speaker: NA
Text: as the end sought should be provision for

Speaker: NA
Text: a more rapid writing-off of plant on

Speaker: NA
Text: account of obsolescence or for other

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons, the existing provisions could be

Speaker: NA
Text: used and adapted satisfactorily.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t does not seem to be appreciated as

Speaker: NA
Text: widely as it might, even by the more sober

Speaker: NA
Text: opinion to wbich I have just referred,

Speaker: NA
Text: that although'the present rates of depre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciation provided in the act are based on

Speaker: NA
Text: what is called the effective life of an

Speaker: NA
Text: asset, it is nevertheless possible for the

Speaker: NA
Text: owner of the asset to scrap it at an earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: date and then claim the amount by

Speaker: NA
Text: which the realization price falls short of

Speaker: NA
Text: the written-down value as a deduction

Speaker: NA
Text: for income tax purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Notwithstanding this little-understood

Speaker: NA
Text: provision of the existing law, criticism

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to concentrate mainly on the rates

Speaker: NA
Text: of depreciation allowed for various types

Speaker: NA
Text: of assets. Without saying whether such

Speaker: NA
Text: criticism is justified or not, I think this

Speaker: NA
Text: is a matter upon which the public mind

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to be set at ease and with this in

Speaker: NA
Text: view the Government has decided to refer

Speaker: NA
Text: this aspect of the matter to a special

Speaker: NA
Text: committee for independent inquiry and

Speaker: NA
Text: report. I t seems to us that such an

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry is a necessary first step i f we are

Speaker: NA
Text: to consider this question from the point

Speaker: NA
Text: of view of national interest. To accept

Speaker: NA
Text: blindly the pleas of sectional advocates

Speaker: NA
Text: in such a highly technical field would

Speaker: NA
Text: endanger that high purpose, and this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government will be no party to it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has decided that a

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentarian should be chairman of the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee and it has chosen Mr Alan

Speaker: NA
Text: Hulme, the honorable member for Petrie,

Speaker: NA
Text: to undertake that assignment. Four other

Speaker: NA
Text: members will be chosen from men actively

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged respectively in manufacturing,'

Speaker: NA
Text: commerce, primary industry and the

Speaker: NA
Text: accountancy profession.

Text: CONCLUSION.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,050,100,000 I n surveying tbe outlook, the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has found some grounds for caution

Speaker: NA
Text: and some reason to stress the approach of

Speaker: NA
Text: weightier national responsibilities for Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,015,100,000 tralia. But tbe caution we suggest is in

Speaker: NA
Text: the main a caution against over-exuber-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance; the responsibilities we foresee

Speaker: NA
Text: should be well within our strength. A l l in

Speaker: NA
Text: all, conditions are favorable to further

Speaker: NA
Text: sound progress in the year ahead. The

Speaker: NA
Text: main thing is for the various elements in

Speaker: NA
Text: our economy to keep in step and not try,

Speaker: NA
Text: 251,000 each individually, to thrust itself forward

Speaker: NA
Text: at the expense of the others.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n this budget we have observed the

Speaker: NA
Text: essential principle that, during times when

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation's capacity is almost fully

Speaker: NA
Text: extended, revenue should at least balance

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure. We have been able to do this

Speaker: NA
Text: while providing not only for certain neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sarily larger commitments but also for

Speaker: NA
Text: active encouragement through tax reduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions to effort, saving and enterprise. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a similar determination through-

Speaker: NA
Text: out the whole economy to consolidate

Speaker: NA
Text: totalling stability without the sacrifice of initiative,

Speaker: NA
Text: we can face tbe future with firm

Speaker: NA
Text: oonfidence.

Speaker: Sir ARTHUR FADDEN
Text: MCPherson-

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer) [9.11] - I move-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of this, bill, in_ conjunction

Speaker: NA
Text: with a resolution which I shall move later,

Speaker: NA
Text: is to give effect, to. sales tax concessions

Speaker: NA
Text: involving a loss to revenue of £12,822,000

Speaker: NA
Text: iu a full financial year,, and £9,892,000 in

Speaker: NA
Text: the. current financial year. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment haa taken much care to select con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessions which will either contribute to

Speaker: NA
Text: the reduction, of costs in industry or will

Speaker: NA
Text: be of assistance to home builders and

Speaker: NA
Text: furnishers.. Particular consideration, has

Speaker: NA
Text: been given to the effect of sales, tax upon

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial costs, because the. Government

Speaker: NA
Text: regards th® minimizing, of suchi costs, of

Speaker: NA
Text: great, importance..

Speaker: NA
Text: Ashonorable members' know, manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facturers already enjoy exemption, from

Speaker: NA
Text: EADDBNI)' sales tax in respect of machinery and

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment used by them in manufacturing

Speaker: NA
Text: operations'. Persons: engageds in the

Speaker: NA
Text: mining industry also benefit from* an

Speaker: NA
Text: exemption of plant used in mining opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions, and in treating theproducts of these

Speaker: NA
Text: operations,, but neither has been able in

Speaker: NA
Text: the past to purchase machinery and plant

Speaker: NA
Text: used i n the repair of their manufacturing

Speaker: NA
Text: or producing plant without payment of

Speaker: NA
Text: sales tax on it. This bill provides for the

Speaker: NA
Text: exemption of the plant used by manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facturers and persons engaged in the

Speaker: NA
Text: mining industry in the repair or main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tenance of their machinery.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are other new exemptions de-

Speaker: NA
Text: signed to reduce costs. Exemption is

Speaker: NA
Text: being granted in respect of machinery

Speaker: NA
Text: and equipment used for business purposes

Speaker: NA
Text: in the servicing or repair of motor

Speaker: NA
Text: vehicles and aircraft. Equipment used

Speaker: NA
Text: in business operations in the construction,

Speaker: NA
Text: repair or maintenance of buildings, roads,

Speaker: NA
Text: dams and other works will also be exempt.

Speaker: NA
Text: Machinery used by boot repairers will be

Speaker: NA
Text: exempt. Exemption is being granted in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of safety equipment for use in

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial operations, and also in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of clock systems and time-recording

Speaker: NA
Text: apparatus for use for business or indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial purposes, other than clocks and

Speaker: NA
Text: watches which remain subject to tax at

Speaker: NA
Text: the rate of 16$ per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Hand tools of a kind used for industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes are to be exempt. This exemp-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion will contribute to the reduction of

Speaker: NA
Text: costs in industry and, in addition, will

Speaker: NA
Text: help artisans and home purchasers of

Speaker: NA
Text: such tools. Manufacturers of carbonated

Speaker: NA
Text: beverages, whose problems of costs appear

Speaker: NA
Text: to be particularly acute, have long

Speaker: NA
Text: complained of having to pay tax on the

Speaker: NA
Text: containers in which their goods ai'e sold

Speaker: NA
Text: because of a deposit charged thereon.

Speaker: NA
Text: Exemption is now being allowed in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of bottles and cases, or crates,

Speaker: NA
Text: for use in the marketing of their products.

Speaker: NA
Text: Vendors of goods generally, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: retailers, will have their costs reduced by

Speaker: NA
Text: a new exemption of paper bags, wrap-

Speaker: NA
Text: ping paper and string used to wrap up

Speaker: NA
Text: and secure goods for delivery. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: a wide demand for exemption of furni-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture and household goods. These goods

Speaker: NA
Text: cover a very wide range, indeed, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of a complete exemption would be

Speaker: NA
Text: so heavy as to render this impracticable

Speaker: NA
Text: at present. It is proposed, however, to

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce from the general rate of 12-J per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, to a special rate of 10 per cent, a

Speaker: NA
Text: wide range of furniture and household

Speaker: NA
Text: goods as specified in the bill. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: believed that this will appreciably reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: the costs of home establishment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir Arthur Fadden.

Speaker: NA
Text: Exemption is being granted in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of aeroplanes for all purposes. The

Speaker: NA
Text: limited field of exemptions included when

Speaker: NA
Text: the sales tax legislation was first intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced in 1930, did not include aeroplanes.

Speaker: NA
Text: But, in 1934, when the list of exemptions

Speaker: NA
Text: was generally revised, provision was made

Speaker: NA
Text: for exemption of aeroplanes. This

Speaker: NA
Text: exemption remained in force until

Speaker: NA
Text: November, 1940, when, because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: exigencies of war, a number of exemp-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions was withdrawn, including that

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to aeroplanes. Last year, the

Speaker: NA
Text: law was amended to authorize exemption

Speaker: NA
Text: of aircraft other than those used for

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial purposes. This was done

Speaker: NA
Text: largely as the result of requests for relief

Speaker: NA
Text: from tax on behalf of aero clubs, which

Speaker: NA
Text: render valuable service to the community

Speaker: NA
Text: in the teaching of flying. A thorough

Speaker: NA
Text: examination made since that date has

Speaker: NA
Text: disclosed that the imposition of sales tax

Speaker: NA
Text: on aeroplanes would impose a heavy

Speaker: NA
Text: burden on commercial airline operators,

Speaker: NA
Text: resulting in the substantial inflation of

Speaker: NA
Text: their already heavy costs of new aircraft

Speaker: NA
Text: and would, in due course, be reflected in

Speaker: NA
Text: higher fare and freight costs. The prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem of costs of these operators has been

Speaker: NA
Text: accentuated by the necessity to expend

Speaker: NA
Text: large sums of money in the purchase of a

Speaker: NA
Text: considerable number of new aircraft at

Speaker: NA
Text: the present time in order to replace old

Speaker: NA
Text: machines and maintain efficient service.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is relevant to note also i n this con-

Speaker: NA
Text: nexion, that ships are not subject to

Speaker: NA
Text: sales tax whilst railway rolling stock

Speaker: NA
Text: does not bear sales tax because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: exemption of government departments.

Speaker: NA
Text: For these reasons it has been decided to

Speaker: NA
Text: make the exemption absolute so as to

Speaker: NA
Text: exempt these goods regardless of the pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose of their use, as was the case before

Speaker: NA
Text: 1940. The exemption will apply not only

Speaker: NA
Text: to freight and passenger airliners, but

Speaker: NA
Text: also to aircraft used for agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes in spraying or spreading fer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tilizer or seed. The exemption of aero-

Speaker: NA
Text: planes is to be made effective as from the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1st January, 1946. The reasons for this

Speaker: NA
Text: decision are:-First , that exemption

Speaker: NA
Text: applied to Trans-Australia Airlines until

Speaker: NA
Text: 1952, when it was made subject to tax;

Speaker: NA
Text: secondly, exemption was granted to the

Speaker: NA
Text: British Commonwealth Pacific Airlines

Speaker: NA
Text: Limited and Qantas Airways Limited in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1946 and 1947, respectively; and, thirdly,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government now believes that it

Speaker: NA
Text: would have been just and proper to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: store the exemption which existed for

Speaker: NA
Text: aeroplanes from 1934 to 1940 imme-

Speaker: NA
Text: diately the war ended and the develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of air transport services in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia was resumed.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is the clearly stated nolicy of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government that competition between

Speaker: NA
Text: Government airlines and privately owned

Speaker: NA
Text: airlines shall be on equal terms. The

Speaker: NA
Text: pre-dating of the exemption of aeroplanes

Speaker: NA
Text: will remove some inconsistencies of treat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment as between the Government airlines

Speaker: NA
Text: and several private operators. I n the

Speaker: NA
Text: course of the examination of this subject,

Speaker: NA
Text: it was discovered that some aeroplanes

Speaker: NA
Text: have been imported and put into opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion without sales tax having been paid

Speaker: NA
Text: upon them. This was due to an irregular

Speaker: NA
Text: but inadvertent use of registered tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: payers' certificates, and to the belief that

Speaker: NA
Text: the same freedom from sales tax that

Speaker: NA
Text: applied to the Government airlines would

Speaker: NA
Text: apply also to other commercial transport

Speaker: NA
Text: systems. The exemption which is now

Speaker: NA
Text: being enacted will obviato the necessity

Speaker: NA
Text: for retrospective action to collect the tax

Speaker: NA
Text: not paid and will, at the same time, sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantially restore equality of treatment

Speaker: NA
Text: to all competing lines. The back-dating

Speaker: NA
Text: of, the exemption may necessitate certain

Speaker: NA
Text: refunds, but these will be comparatively

Speaker: NA
Text: small, and they will be payable mainly to

Speaker: NA
Text: small airline operators and aero clubs.

Speaker: NA
Text: The exemption of parts of aeroplanes will

Speaker: NA
Text: not come into operation, however, until

Speaker: NA
Text: the 19th August, 1954, the date of com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mencement of the amending bill. Though

Speaker: NA
Text: it is realized that this will still leave

Speaker: NA
Text: Government airlines in a position of

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage compared with

Speaker: NA
Text: operators so far as transactions prior to

Speaker: NA
Text: November, 1952, are concerned, the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment has not been able to go so far

Speaker: NA
Text: as to remedy this anomaly. The Civil

Speaker: NA
Text: Aviation Agreement Act 1952 ensures

Speaker: NA
Text: equality of treatment from the date of its

Speaker: NA
Text: enactment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ice cream, confectionery, musical

Speaker: NA
Text: instruments and toys and associated

Speaker: NA
Text: goods are at present subject to tax at the

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum rate of 16jj per cent. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has had continuous and

Speaker: NA
Text: pressing representations concerning the

Speaker: NA
Text: effect of increasing costs on the market for

Speaker: NA
Text: these commodities. Though, in some

Speaker: NA
Text: senses, they may be regarded as less essen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial commodities, they occupy a very

Speaker: NA
Text: definite place in the economy, some using

Speaker: NA
Text: large quantities of primary products and

Speaker: NA
Text: all providing much work in a variety

Speaker: NA
Text: of industries. To prevent the tax

Speaker: NA
Text: becoming too regressive in its effect, it has

Speaker: NA
Text: been decided to transfer these goods to

Speaker: NA
Text: the general classification and henceforth

Speaker: NA
Text: they will be subject to tax at 12-J per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tlie bill contains numerous other new

Speaker: NA
Text: exemptions and re-expressions of exist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing exemptions designed to remove anoma-

Speaker: NA
Text: lies and difficulties associated with their

Speaker: NA
Text: administration. For example, leather,

Speaker: NA
Text: solder, methylated spirits and iron and

Speaker: NA
Text: steel wire of gauges 15 to 18, are goods

Speaker: NA
Text: which have hitherto only been exempt

Speaker: NA
Text: when purchased for certain purposes, and

Speaker: NA
Text: certificates as to those purposes were a

Speaker: NA
Text: pre-requisite to the obtaining of exemp-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. They will now be exempt uncondi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionally, thus relieving purchasers of the

Speaker: NA
Text: obligation to furnish certificates as to the

Speaker: NA
Text: intended use of the goods. The agricul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tural industry will benefit by a new

Speaker: NA
Text: exemption for live-stock carriers of the

Speaker: NA
Text: kind attached to motor vehicles or wagons.

Speaker: NA
Text: Seed-cleaning machinery is being

Speaker: NA
Text: exempted and the exemptions of goods for

Speaker: NA
Text: use in tho destruction of animal pests

Speaker: NA
Text: have been revised to remove anomalies

Speaker: NA
Text: arising from previous limitations. Exemp-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is now authorized in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: poisons and traps for the destruction of

Speaker: NA
Text: all classes of noxious animals. Materials

Speaker: NA
Text: the other than fertilizers, for use in the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: provement of crops, are also being brought

Speaker: NA
Text: private within the scope of the exemptions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Exemptions of surgical goods are being

Speaker: NA
Text: extended to cover certain classes of goods

Speaker: NA
Text: which are used to overcome physical

Speaker: NA
Text: disabilities, and provision is being made

Speaker: NA
Text: for exemption of certain goods used in

Speaker: NA
Text: the cleaning of teeth and massaging of

Speaker: NA
Text: gums to minimize dental decay. I n the

Speaker: NA
Text: past, physiotherapists have not ' been

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled to exemption of surgical equip-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment which has been free of tax when

Speaker: NA
Text: purchased by hospitals or medical prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: titioners. As the work of physiothera-

Speaker: NA
Text: pists is growing in importance, and is

Speaker: NA
Text: closely associated "with the ^treatment of

Speaker: NA
Text: patients hy medical -practitioners, the

Speaker: NA
Text: law is -being amended to bring 'registered

Speaker: NA
Text: physiotherapists within the scope of the

Speaker: NA
Text: exemption.'

Speaker: NA
Text: An anomaly with regard to certain

Speaker: NA
Text: cleaning and polishing cloths, being

Speaker: NA
Text: articles specially manufactured for those

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes, is also being removed. These

Speaker: NA
Text: goods are sold in competition with articles

Speaker: NA
Text: whic'h have 'been exempt as piece goods,

Speaker: NA
Text: as they were subjected to no other process

Speaker: NA
Text: than cutting from the roll of material as

Speaker: NA
Text: manufactured. Cloths of this kind made

Speaker: NA
Text: fiom piece goods will now be exempt,

Speaker: NA
Text: regardless of the degree of manufacture to

Speaker: NA
Text: which they have been subjected! A state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment setting out full details 'Of the amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments has heen .circulated for the infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation of honorable -members. This bill

Speaker: NA
Text: gives concessions ov.esr :a wide area and

Speaker: NA
Text: I com.fidently recommend i t for the

Speaker: NA
Text: approval -of honorable members.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr CALWELX)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tariff .19.21-19,53. The proposed customs

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments are, in the main, basprl upon

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations made by the Comon-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Tariff Board in comparatively

Speaker: NA
Text: asecent reports. At a later .stage this

Speaker: NA
Text: evening .1 shall avail myself <of the oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to tahle the relevant Tariff Board

Speaker: NA
Text: reports. The proposed -duties w i l l oper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate ias from to-morrow morning. A

Speaker: NA
Text: ".Summary of Alterations", which has

Speaker: NA
Text: heen circulated to honorable .members sets

Speaker: NA
Text: out .in concise form the proposed tariff

Speaker: NA
Text: 'variations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The main customs changes relate to

Speaker: NA
Text: cotton -canvas -and -cotton duck piece

Speaker: NA
Text: goods, filament lamps of the types ordi-

Speaker: NA
Text: narily used in motor vehicles for lighting

Speaker: NA
Text: -purposes, -cooking stoves and cooking

Speaker: NA
Text: ranges which operate on the heat storage

Speaker: NA
Text: -principle, formaldehyde, true vegetable

Speaker: NA
Text: parchment paper, 'and paper bobbins,

Speaker: NA
Text: pirns, reels, &c, for the types used in the

Speaker: NA
Text: weaving and spinning industries. I n each

Speaker: NA
Text: instance the proposed -variations arise

Speaker: NA
Text: from inquiries conducted 'by the Tariff

Speaker: NA
Text: Board. Increased duties are proposed on

Speaker: NA
Text: cotton canvas and cotton duck piece goods,

Speaker: NA
Text: heat storage cooking 'stoves and cooking

Speaker: NA
Text: ranges with an oven roasting capacity of

Speaker: NA
Text: not more than 4,000 cubic inches, formal-

Speaker: NA
Text: dehyde, true vegetable parchment paper,

Speaker: NA
Text: and paper bobbins, pirns, &c. Reduced

Speaker: NA
Text: duties are proposed with respect to metal

Speaker: NA
Text: filament lamps of the type's ordinarily

Speaker: NA
Text: used i n motor "vehicles for lighting pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: poses, and heat storage cooking stoves

Speaker: NA
Text: and ranges with an oven roasting capa-

Speaker: NA
Text: city in excess of 4,000 cubic inches.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other customs amendments are those

Speaker: NA
Text: covering clocks, n.e.i -fo r example, alarm

Speaker: NA
Text: and household clocks-cloc k movements,

Speaker: NA
Text: and brandy in respect of which reduced

Speaker: NA
Text: duties are, in each instance proposed. For

Speaker: NA
Text: administrative reasons it has been neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary to vary the wording of the customs

Speaker: NA
Text: items covering fork-lift trucks, hog de-

Speaker: NA
Text: hairing machines and punching and

Speaker: NA
Text: shearing machines. The rates of duty

Speaker: NA
Text: have not, however, been varied.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposed amendment to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Customs Tariff .(Canadian Preference)

Speaker: NA
Text: 1934-1954 is complementary to the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed .amendment made in the Customs

Speaker: NA
Text: Tariff 1933-19:54 with respect to fork-lift

Speaker: NA
Text: trucks. The rates of duty remain

Speaker: NA
Text: unchanged.

Speaker: NA
Text: The only excise amendment proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: relates to a -reduction of 30s. a proof

Speaker: NA
Text: gallon on locally produced brandy. Tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction is designed to assist the grape-

Speaker: NA
Text: growing industry. Present indications

Speaker: NA
Text: are that .a large quantity of wine .grapes

Speaker: NA
Text: 'which could .be used for the distillation, of

Speaker: NA
Text: brandy will remain unharvested from

Speaker: NA
Text: the next .'season's crop ''Unless some action

Speaker: NA
Text: is .taken -to create a demand for these

Speaker: NA
Text: grapes. The revenue loss arising from

Speaker: NA
Text: this excise concession will be approxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately £400,'0.00 for the .remainder of the

Speaker: NA
Text: present financial .year and about £468,000

Speaker: NA
Text: for a full .year. Honorable members will,

Speaker: NA
Text: -of course, be (accorded full opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: -at a later .stage to discuss these Proposals.

Speaker: NA
Text: Progress reported.

Speaker: NA
Text: . Mr -DEAN (Robertson) [9.31]| -Thi s

Speaker: NA
Text: afternoon, the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Batman ( Mr Bird) voiced some criti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cism of 'the Colombo plan. Probably

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements made under the plan have

Speaker: NA
Text: not always been "So satisfactory -as the

Speaker: NA
Text: majority of us hoped they would be, but

Speaker: NA
Text: that is true of any form of assistance that

Speaker: NA
Text: is granted, whether within Australia, or

Speaker: NA
Text: to another country. Accomplishments

Speaker: NA
Text: always fall short of hopes and plans.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nevertheless, the plain fact is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Colombo plan, in itself, has made a

Speaker: NA
Text: tremendous contribution to the welfare of

Speaker: NA
Text: countries to the north of Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: plan has made a physical contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: to tlieir welfare because they have

Speaker: NA
Text: received technical equipment and food

Speaker: NA
Text: supplies, and has assisted them in another

Speaker: NA
Text: important way through the exchange of

Speaker: NA
Text: persons and ideas. For example, execu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive officers and students from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Colombo plan countries have visited

Speaker: NA
Text: AustraUa in -order to gain at first hand

Speaker: NA
Text: a knowledge of the ways and workings

Speaker: NA
Text: of democracy. Australia has sent tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nical missions to those countries, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for External Affairs ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Casey), in answer to a question this

Speaker: NA
Text: afternoon, informed the House that

Speaker: NA
Text: surgical teams had also been sent to

Speaker: NA
Text: them.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not desire to discuss those matters

Speaker: NA
Text: at length, because extensive reference

Speaker: NA
Text: was made to them in the debate on inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national affairs. However, I should like

Speaker: NA
Text: to repeat a suggestion that I made in that

Speaker: NA
Text: debate for the despatch by Australia of

Speaker: NA
Text: tonms to Asian countries that are

Speaker: NA
Text: threatened by the onward march of com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munism. Honorable members will recall

Speaker: NA
Text: that I suggested that we send " teams for

Speaker: NA
Text: democracy" to those countries, because

Speaker: NA
Text: I feel sure that despite the recent peace

Speaker: NA
Text: that has been gained in Viet Nam, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Communists are already organizing them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves, not only for the elections that will

Speaker: NA
Text: be held in Viet Nam, Laos and Cambodia

Speaker: NA
Text: in approximately two years' time, but also

Speaker: NA
Text: for further conquests. We are not en-

Speaker: NA
Text: gaged now in a " cold war ". This is a

Speaker: NA
Text: -*ar of hot bullets, and the Communists

Speaker: NA
Text: still have effective control of the areas

Speaker: NA
Text: which they have conquered. I warmly

Speaker: NA
Text: support the despatch of technical missions

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Colombo plan countries, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: consider that it would also be of great

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage to the cause of peace and

Speaker: NA
Text: democracy i f we sent working teams to

Speaker: NA
Text: them so that they could see members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the British Commonwealth of Nations in

Speaker: NA
Text: action. The British Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: includes peoples of various races and

Speaker: NA
Text: beliefs, but all of them believe in demo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cracy. I t is a loosely-knit organization,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it has set an example to the world of

Speaker: NA
Text: how a number of countries can live

Speaker: NA
Text: together and progress together that no

Speaker: NA
Text: other combination of nations has been

Speaker: NA
Text: able to give.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Governor-General said, in his

Speaker: NA
Text: Speech-

Speaker: NA
Text: My Government is undertaking a re-organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: zation of the defence programme to achieve

Speaker: NA
Text: thc maximum secui'ity that the country can

Speaker: NA
Text: provide for a long period, having regard to

Speaker: NA
Text: the needs not only of defence but also of

Speaker: NA
Text: economic stability, a steady development of

Speaker: NA
Text: population and resources, and high levels of

Speaker: NA
Text: production and employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I listened with interest this afternoon

Speaker: NA
Text: tr. the speech of the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Henty ( Mr Gullett), and I think that

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Dean.

Speaker: NA
Text: all honorable members will agree with his

Speaker: NA
Text: statement on the necessity for the adop-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of certain measures for the military

Speaker: NA
Text: defence of Australia. He also spoke

Speaker: NA
Text: about the security of our country, not in

Speaker: NA
Text: reference to espionage or counter

Speaker: NA
Text: espionage, but in the sense of national

Speaker: NA
Text: prosperity and development. I should

Speaker: NA
Text: like to develop that matter for a few

Speaker: NA
Text: moments. We in Australia are now in a

Speaker: NA
Text: fortunate and prosperous state. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: it is true to say that it is a long time since

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has been in such a fortunate

Speaker: NA
Text: economic condition in so many ways.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of our primary industries are i n a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong economic position. The wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: industry has its problems, but they are

Speaker: NA
Text: being dealt with separately. The dairy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing industry has had several problems,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially in recent years, and they are

Speaker: NA
Text: being dealt with separately. The small

Speaker: NA
Text: farmer, such as the orchardist, the citrus-

Speaker: NA
Text: grower, the poultry-farmer and the pig-

Speaker: NA
Text: farmer, has some serious problems at the

Speaker: NA
Text: present time. I f Australia is to be made

Speaker: NA
Text: economically secure, the problems of the

Speaker: NA
Text: smaller primary industries must be

Speaker: NA
Text: speedily solved. Those industries must

Speaker: NA
Text: be stabilized, and the producers engaged

Speaker: NA
Text: in them must receive a worthwhile return

Speaker: NA
Text: for their labour and for the capital that

Speaker: NA
Text: they have invested in their properties.

Speaker: NA
Text: On a number of occasions during the

Speaker: NA
Text: last twelve months, honorable members on

Speaker: NA
Text: this side of the House, including myself,

Speaker: NA
Text: have made representations on behalf of

Speaker: NA
Text: the poultry industry, and the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has been able to take action to overcome

Speaker: NA
Text: some of its difficulties. At the beginning

Speaker: NA
Text: of the year, £250,000 was made available

Speaker: NA
Text: to the industry to assist it to overcome

Speaker: NA
Text: a difficulty caused by a fall in the price

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian eggs sold on the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom market. The industry still has

Speaker: NA
Text: some problems to solve. There are short-

Speaker: NA
Text: term problems, in respect of which imme-

Speaker: NA
Text: diate assistance is required, and long-

Speaker: NA
Text: term problems, which involve long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: planning to stabilize the industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Assistance could be in the form of a

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidy on stock-feed wheat, or financial

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance to poultry-farmers in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: nexion with the export of eggs to the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Kingdom, or direct financial

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance to egg producers, given through

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Egg Board and dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tributed by the State Egg Boards. My

Speaker: NA
Text: view is that direct financial assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: would be of most benefit to the industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have mentioned these matters because

Speaker: NA
Text: I think i t is necessary to remind the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament that some of our small p r

Speaker: NA
Text: mary industries are i n urgent need of

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me deal briefly with the citrus

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry and give a resume of a letter

Speaker: NA
Text: have received. The writer states that

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the problems with which the into

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry is faced is that i n the case

Speaker: NA
Text: many of its products supply is in excess

Speaker: NA
Text: of demand. That problem is shared by

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the other small primary indusproduced

Speaker: NA
Text: tries but, according to this letter, the

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty is not so widespread i n the distributed.

Speaker: NA
Text: citrus industry, because in some areas

Speaker: NA
Text: the production per tree is much greater

Speaker: NA
Text: than i n others, and in those areas the

Speaker: NA
Text: overhead expenses of production are

Speaker: NA
Text: paratively low. That comment expresses

Speaker: NA
Text: a sectional viewpoint because i t applies

Speaker: NA
Text: only to certain areas. Other areas

Speaker: NA
Text: affected to a greater degree. The writer them is the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: states-

Speaker: NA
Text: The whole thing is indeed a, complex

Speaker: NA
Text: lem, and there is a feeling within the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: tliat there should be some price support or

Speaker: NA
Text: guarantee for these small primary industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: It does not seem just that every industry

Speaker: NA
Text: all labour has some sort of guarantee

Speaker: NA
Text: profit, whereas the smaller farmer, who

Speaker: NA
Text: the backbone of so much of our primary

Speaker: NA
Text: industry and our national wealth, should

Speaker: NA
Text: out on a limb, as i t were, without very

Speaker: NA
Text: people caring about his problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: That comment expresses the genuine

Speaker: NA
Text: belief of a number of the smaller primary

Speaker: NA
Text: producers. I agree that some of their

Speaker: NA
Text: problems, especially marketing problems,

Speaker: NA
Text: are the direct responsibility of the various

Speaker: NA
Text: State governments, but those governments

Speaker: NA
Text: are not accepting their responsibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although they say they are doing everyit

Speaker: NA
Text: thing i n their power to assist primary

Speaker: NA
Text: producers, they have doubled the freight

Speaker: NA
Text: on primary products and i n that

Speaker: NA
Text: added to the problems with which the principal reasons for the

Speaker: NA
Text: primary producers are faced.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to digress fo r a moment to speak

Speaker: NA
Text: of the supply of materials to primary

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers as a whole. There has been quite

Speaker: NA
Text: a lot of comment recently, especially i

Speaker: NA
Text: the country press, about what has been

Speaker: NA
Text: called a reduction of the supply of

Speaker: NA
Text: fencing wire, galvanized iron, galvanized

Speaker: NA
Text: iron piping and superphosphate. I sliall

Speaker: NA
Text: not deal with superphosphate, because

Speaker: NA
Text: was dealt with this afternoon by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister f o r Commerce and Agriculture

Speaker: NA
Text: body at the morgue and they hardly recognized

Speaker: NA
Text: him. They identified him by a scar on his

Speaker: NA
Text: caused from a burn with hot lead as a

Text: My married daughter asked i f she could

Text: ways. It has affected our health.

Text: band had ten weeks off work with

Speaker: NA
Text: Hr. Griffiths.

Speaker: NA
Text: everything they needed for school, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: against its possible failure, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: tant loss of life and valuable equipment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tf a blunder was made, it is the duty

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Government to admit the fact, to

Speaker: NA
Text: pay compensation, and take the action

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary to ensure that such a happening

Speaker: NA
Text: will not occur again. The alternative is

Speaker: NA
Text: that i f a blunder was not made, then this

Speaker: NA
Text: tragic happening assumes almost

Speaker: NA
Text: criminal proportions, and those respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible for the loss of life caused by it

Speaker: NA
Text: should be punished. A satisfactory

Speaker: NA
Text: settlement of the matter involves the

Speaker: NA
Text: answering of many searching questions

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been asked, and the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: should let the general public have the

Speaker: NA
Text: answers to them. The relatives of the

Speaker: NA
Text: lads who lost their lives and the people

Speaker: NA
Text: generally, want answers to the following

Speaker: NA
Text: questions:-1 . What regulations cover

Speaker: NA
Text: amphibious training operations, and

Speaker: NA
Text: were these regulations fully complied

Speaker: NA
Text: with ? 2. Was the Army command aware

Speaker: NA
Text: that the operations being undertaken

Speaker: NA
Text: would involve the amphibious vehicles

Speaker: NA
Text: covering a distance of more than 40 miles

Speaker: NA
Text: by open sea? 3. What expert authority

Speaker: NA
Text: certified the craft as seaworthy, and was

Speaker: NA
Text: a certificate obtained from the Navigation

Speaker: NA
Text: Department to that effect 4. Have

Speaker: NA
Text: similar craft elsewhere been used pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: viously for operations in the open sea,

Speaker: NA
Text: or are such craft normally used in ship-to-

Speaker: NA
Text: shore operations from mother ships?

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. Was the Navigation Department

Speaker: NA
Text: advised of the manoeuvre and, i f so, was

Speaker: NA
Text: it informed that should distress signals

Speaker: NA
Text: be fired no aid would be required from

Speaker: NA
Text: the navigation authorities? 6. I f the

Speaker: NA
Text: navigation authorities were not informed

Speaker: NA
Text: of -the manceuvre, why did the officer on

Speaker: NA
Text: duty at Nobby's not send out the pilot

Speaker: NA
Text: boat to investigate the reason for the

Speaker: NA
Text: firing of distress rockets? 7. Why did

Speaker: NA
Text: wireless communication fail so quickly

Speaker: NA
Text: between all vehicles, i f the sea was safe?

Speaker: NA
Text: Other questions involving engine

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity, the pumping system, signalling

Speaker: NA
Text: lights, navigation lights, radio protection

Speaker: NA
Text: from shipped seas, and whether open

Speaker: NA
Text: craft, such as were used in this manceuvre,

Speaker: NA
Text: with approximately only 18 inches of

Speaker: NA
Text: freeboard, are capable of discharging

Speaker: NA
Text: water shipped from heavy seas, also

Speaker: NA
Text: require answering before relatives of the

Speaker: NA
Text: bereaved and the general public will be

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfied that the operation was intended

Speaker: NA
Text: resulto be anything more than a stunt or a

Speaker: NA
Text: picnic affair. Too many conflicting

Speaker: NA
Text: stories have been told about this tragic

Speaker: NA
Text: happening. The coroner was told that

Speaker: NA
Text: the sea was almost normal. Yet on the

Speaker: NA
Text: morning of the disaster the press every-

Speaker: NA
Text: where in Australia told of huge seas along

Speaker: NA
Text: the coast and of the record life-saving

Speaker: NA
Text: efforts that life-savers on the beaches had

Speaker: NA
Text: to make to save bathers from drowning.

Speaker: NA
Text: No fewer than 349 beach rescues were

Speaker: NA
Text: made between Sydney and Newcastle.

Speaker: NA
Text: A headline that appeared in the Newcastle

Speaker: NA
Text: Morning Herald and Miners' Advocate

Speaker: NA
Text: cn the 8th March, which was the day of

Speaker: NA
Text: the tragedy, read-

Speaker: NA
Text: 349 rescues from sea in 2 areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: The press stories told of such incidents

Speaker: NA
Text: on the previous day as a surf ski, which

Speaker: NA
Text: was to be used in a championship beach

Speaker: NA
Text: event, having been smashed by heavy

Speaker: NA
Text: seas. I t was not until late in the after-

Speaker: NA
Text: noon of the 8th March that Newcastle

Speaker: NA
Text: residents received the news of what was

Speaker: NA
Text: described as a shocking military disaster

Speaker: NA
Text: in Stockton Bight. At first, the news of

Speaker: NA
Text: the disaster was vague. Rumours regard-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the number of deaths varied. Parents,

Speaker: NA
Text: relatives and friends of the men were

Speaker: NA
Text: making frantic and frenzied inquiries

Speaker: NA
Text: about lads who were to take part in the

Speaker: NA
Text: amphibious operation. Telephone lines

Speaker: NA
Text: were choked. I n fact, it was impossible to

Speaker: NA
Text: obtain a clear picture of what had hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pened. For a time newspaper reporters

Speaker: NA
Text: were able .to obtain a little information

Speaker: NA
Text: about the disaster., but a complete ban

Speaker: NA
Text: was -soon placed -on the release of news,

Speaker: NA
Text: :and people could find out nothing about

Speaker: NA
Text: -the matter. I t was not until the next .day

Speaker: NA
Text: that .a clear picture emerged, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: became known that 184 members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fifteenth Northern .Rivers Lancers, -com-

Speaker: NA
Text: prising officers and men iof the Citizen

Speaker: NA
Text: Military Forces, and .national service

Speaker: NA
Text: trainees, had been through a terrifying

Speaker: NA
Text: ordeal. Three men liad lost their lives

Speaker: NA
Text: and much valuable machinery and equip-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment had been lost.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I see it this sad and unfortunate

Speaker: NA
Text: accident should .never have been allowed

Speaker: NA
Text: to happen. Someone blundered badly

Speaker: NA
Text: when the operation was sanctioned. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: .generally known that amphibious opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions are something new for the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian .Army. Jn fact, if my memory

Speaker: NA
Text: serves me correctly, amphibious units

Speaker: NA
Text: have been established in the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Army only since the .end of World War

Speaker: NA
Text: EL, and any experience gained by Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians in respect of this class of opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, or the capabilities of the vehicles

Speaker: NA
Text: took part in the operation, has been

Speaker: NA
Text: gained as a result of Australian participa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in such operations .carried out

Speaker: NA
Text: by the TJnited States Army in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific islands during the last war,

Speaker: NA
Text: when similar craft were used in

Speaker: NA
Text: ship to shore operations and for covering

Speaker: NA
Text: beachhead landings. The general public

Speaker: NA
Text: -wants to know who was responsible for the

Speaker: NA
Text: happening and why it was allowed to take

Speaker: NA
Text: place. Ever since the day of the tragedy,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for the Army has refused to

Speaker: NA
Text: -di vulge the findings of the military court

Speaker: NA
Text: of inquiry which, incidently, apparently

Speaker: NA
Text: had to sit on two occasions before the

Speaker: NA
Text: High Command was 'satisfied that it had

Speaker: NA
Text: obtained answers that would satisfy the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. Only an open public inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: could solve this matter to the satisfaction

Speaker: NA
Text: of the bereaved parents and parents whose

Speaker: NA
Text: sons took part in the operation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister refuses to allow such an inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: to be held. I tell him now that if he had

Speaker: NA
Text: been -contesting either the Newcastle

Speaker: NA
Text: or the Shortland electorate at the last

Speaker: NA
Text: general election he would now be out

Speaker: NA
Text: of a job, such is public indignation in

Speaker: NA
Text: -these electorates about his attitude. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister bas accused the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Newcastle (MT. Watkins) and me

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Griffiths.

Speaker: NA
Text: of trying to .make political capital out -of

Speaker: NA
Text: this tragic (occurrence ibecause we 'sought

Speaker: NA
Text: an open public inquiry, which -was being

Speaker: NA
Text: demanded by "the parents and rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives of the troops (concerned, as well as

Speaker: NA
Text: iby the general public. The .Minister isaid

Speaker: NA
Text: that he l a s -nothing fiurither ito add about

Speaker: NA
Text: tihe disaster ;aaid that he is satisfied with

Speaker: NA
Text: .the finding of the court of inquiry. He

Speaker: NA
Text: has said that no officer was to hlame, .and

Speaker: NA
Text: that no irregularities occurred. Neither

Speaker: NA
Text: the ,peo,ple nor I accept the Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: assurances. They do not influence -me, or

Speaker: NA
Text: the thousands of people whose sons may

Speaker: NA
Text: meet a similar fate i n the future unless

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter is fully ^probed, the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: truth .about it is told .and proper safe-

Speaker: NA
Text: guards taken. Too many contradictory

Speaker: NA
Text: statements liave been made about the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole matter. By refusing to hold a

Speaker: NA
Text: public inquiry the Minister and his

Speaker: NA
Text: departmental officers are obviously hiding,

Speaker: NA
Text: behind the coroner's finding. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: the witnesses who appeared at the

Speaker: NA
Text: coroner's inquiry were .selected witnesses,

Speaker: NA
Text: because only twelve out of the 184 men

Speaker: NA
Text: who took part i n the manoeuvre were called

Speaker: NA
Text: that to appear before the inquiry, and, accord-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to the press, only seven of them gave

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence. I t appears to me that much

Speaker: NA
Text: has .been concealed. T-he coroner,, who

Speaker: NA
Text: was a farmer, could not possibly cover

Speaker: NA
Text: the mass of material that would be

Speaker: NA
Text: required to carry out a satisfactory

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry because the 'military authorities

Speaker: NA
Text: did not provide the necessary information.

Speaker: NA
Text: A -coroner's duty, as I understand it,

Speaker: NA
Text: is to ascertain the cause of death .and, i n

Speaker: NA
Text: cases i n which doctors refuse to issue a

Speaker: NA
Text: death certificate, to decide whether there

Speaker: NA
Text: were any criminal aspects of the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that many irregularities

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred in relation to this matter. For

Speaker: NA
Text: instance, the commanding officer took his

Speaker: NA
Text: twelve-year-old son on the manoeuvre. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: is alleged that quantities of liquor were

Speaker: NA
Text: in the tanks and that there was .a huge

Speaker: NA
Text: refrigerator in one of the vessels which

Speaker: NA
Text: sank off Morna Point. The Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: s'hould probe these allegations in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to ascertain whether they are true. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: has been said that one lad who ;swam

Speaker: NA
Text: ashore with the twelve-year-old son of the

Speaker: NA
Text: commanding officer could probably have

Speaker: NA
Text: saved the life -of one of the other lads who

Speaker: NA
Text: drowned i f he had not had to look after

Speaker: NA
Text: this boy. The Minister should institute

Speaker: NA
